securityRequirements.description: Development, test and operational facilities shall be separated to reduce the risks of unauthorised access or changes to the operational system.
securityRequirements.note: Production, test and development environment cannot run in the same container / underlying hardware, e.g. virtual machine. Furthermore, depending on the criticality of the system, it is advisable/required to also have a separated networking environment.
securityRequirements.title: Separate development, test and operational equipment

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall use a static code analysis tool to detect vulnerabilities as defined in SECOPS-Moi-DS0005.
securityRequirements.title: Use static code analysis

securityRequirements.description: Test data shall not contain any sensitive information encompassing private personal information (PPI). All sensitive content shall be removed or sufficiently modified before use. The modified data shall not lead to any disclosure.
securityRequirements.note:
System and acceptance testing usually requires substantial volumes of test data that are as close as
possible to operational data.
Therefore, the use of operational databases containing personal information or any other sensitive information
for testing purposes should be avoided. If personal or otherwise sensitive information is used for
testing purposes, all sensitive details and content should be removed or modified beyond recognition
before use. The following guidelines should be applied to protect operational data, when used for
testing purposes:
a) the access control procedures, which apply to operational application systems, should also
apply to test application systems;
b) there should be separate authorization each time operational information is copied to a test
application system;
c) operational information should be erased from a test application system immediately after
the testing is complete;
d) the copying and use of operational information should be logged to provide an audit trail.
securityRequirements.title: Protection of system test data

securityRequirements.description: A change management, configuration control, review and release process shall be established for releasing any change to software.
securityRequirements.note: This should be documented in the Software Management Plan.
securityRequirements.title: Establish change management procedures

securityRequirements.description: The Contractor shall use [Baseline Identifier] [Baseline Document]
securityRequirements.title: Use the baseline document

securityRequirements.description: The process defined for software development applicable to "Suppliers" as specified in [GASF] shall be followed by the contractor.
securityRequirements.note: In [GASF], Section 3 "Structure and usage" provides the explanations on how responsabilities and roles work to be able to idendify for each process and activity, using the RACI charts, which concern a given role (e.g. Supplier roles).
securityRequirements.title: Follow security activities from GASF

securityRequirements.description: Duties and areas of responsibility shall be segregated where possible to reduce opportunities for unauthorised or unintentional modification or misuse of the organisation's assets.
securityRequirements.note:
- A clear separation of approvers, developers, testers and security experts must exist. In some situations, either the same person can or cannot take different roles.
- Different individuals perform information asset support functions (e.g., system management, systems programming, quality assurance/testing, configuration management, and network security).
- Security personnel who administer access control functions should not administer audit functions.
- Mission critical functions and distinct information asset support functions should be divided among different individuals/roles.
securityRequirements.title: Segregate duties and areas of responsibility

securityRequirements.description: No warning shall appear during compilation.
securityRequirements.note: This requirement is related to "Document compiling options".
securityRequirements.title: Compilation shall not have warnings

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements ensure correct procedure for information systems development and their maintenance.
securityRequirements.title: Information systems development and maintenance

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be compliant with ESA Network Security Policy.
securityRequirements.title: Implement ESA compliant system

securityRequirements.description: Cryptographic controls shall be used in compliance with the Security Directives, and where relevant CCSDS Cryptographic recommendations, and by respecting the applicable laws and regulations in consultance with the Project Crypto Custodian (or, if not available, the COMSEC officer) and the SAA (Software Accreditation Authority).
securityRequirements.title: Regulation of cryptographic controls

securityRequirements.description: ESA shall be allowed to audit the software development process at the contractor's site.
securityRequirements.title: Regulation on audit

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements permit to ensure the compliance of the software/system to the relevant agreements, laws, and regulations.
securityRequirements.title: Regulations

note: The following requirements should be considered for inclusion in a SoW when preparing a Statement of Work document.
title: Statement of Work Requirements

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall apply the procedures from the ESA Security Directives for the accessing, handling and storage of information. These procedures ensures the protection of information from improper use or unauthorised divulgation.
securityRequirements.note: For HSO-G, the [applicable Secops Procedure] also apply.
securityRequirements.title: Information handling procedures

securityRequirements.description: The contractor and third party using the information systems shall report all identified and possible security weaknesses in systems or services used by the project or project outcome. Such reports shall be issued at any time and as quickly as possible to the TO.
securityRequirements.note:
This can be any security weakness that is detected during any process of GASF. For example weaknesses can be detected during the development, during the design of the architecture. Such weaknesses shall be reported and reflected in the risk analysis to ensure its coverage or, as last resort, acceptance.
Following actions may expose security weaknesses:
- Secrutiy tools (source code review, tests, etc.)
- Security Events (e.g. the fact that the security event happened is due to a weakness in the system/procedure/etc.).
- Fortuit observation / technology watch (e.g. a weakness was noticed during a review, new information on a weakness)
securityRequirements.title: Reporting security weaknesses

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall report information security events through the TO as fast as possible.
securityRequirements.note:
For HSO-G, the [applicable Secops Procedure] also apply.

Examples of securiity events are:
- Unauthorised access to information (access to documentation, access to source code, etc.)
- Unauthorised modification/integrity of the information (modification of source code)
- Security tests results (source code review, unit tests, etc.)
- Risk Analysis results
- Security awareness session status
- Backup, deployment, integration, etc. strategies
securityRequirements.title: Reporting information security events

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements ensure the proper handling of security incidents through an information security incident management.
securityRequirements.title: Information security incident management

note: The following requirements concern contractual matters such as: legal bindings, official communications channels between ESA and the contractor, penalties, etc.
title: Contractual Requirements

securityRequirements.description: The system shall invalidate session identifiers upon user logout or other session terminations
securityRequirements.note: This curtails the ability of adversaries from capturing and continuing to employ previously valid session IDs.
securityRequirements.title: Invalidate session identifiers at logout

securityRequirements.description: The system shall terminate the network connection associated with a communication session at the end of the session or after a defined [time period of inactivity].
securityRequirements.note: This applies to both internal and external networks. Terminating network connections associated with communications sessions include, for example, de-allocating associated TCP/IP address/port pairs at the operating system level, or de-allocating networking assignments at the application level if multiple application sessions are using a single, operating system-level network connection. Time periods of inactivity may be established by organisations and include, for example, time periods by type of network access or for specific network accesses.
securityRequirements.title: Terminate network connection after session or timeout

securityRequirements.description: The system shall display an explicit logout message to users indicating the reliable termination of authenticated communications sessions.
securityRequirements.note: Logout messages for web page access, for example, can be displayed after authenticated sessions have been terminated. However, for some types of interactive sessions including, for example, file transfer protocol (FTP) sessions, information systems typically send logout messages as final messages prior to terminating sessions.
securityRequirements.title: Display user-initiated logouts

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide a logout capability for user-initiated communications sessions whenever authentication is used to gain access to information resources.
securityRequirements.note: Information resources to which users gain access via authentication include, for example, password-protected websites and web-based services.
securityRequirements.title: Provide user-initiated logout

securityRequirements.note: The following requirement cover the session termination/ending requirement.
securityRequirements.title: Session termination

securityRequirements.description: The information system shall retain the session lock until the user, or another authorised operator, re-establishes access using established identification and authentication procedures.
securityRequirements.note: Session locks are temporary actions taken when users stop work and move away from the immediate vicinity of information systems but do not want to log out because of the temporary nature of their absences. Session locks are implemented where session activities can be determined. This is typically at the operating system level, but can also be at the application level. Session locks are not an acceptable substitute for logging out of information systems, for example, if organizations require users to log out at the end of workdays.
securityRequirements.title: Retain the session lock until the user re-establishes access

securityRequirements.description: The information system shall prevent further access to the system by initiating a session lock after a�[period of inactivity].
securityRequirements.note: Session locks are temporary actions taken when users stop work and move away from the immediate vicinity of information systems but do not want to log out because of the temporary nature of their absences. Session locks are implemented where session activities can be determined. This is typically at the operating system level, but can also be at the application level. Session locks are not an acceptable substitute for logging out of information systems, for example, if organizations require users to log out at the end of workdays.
securityRequirements.title: Automatically lock session after inactivity

securityRequirements.description: The information system shall prevent further access to the system, by locking the session, upon receiving a request from a user.
securityRequirements.note: Session locks are temporary actions taken when users stop work and move away from the immediate vicinity of information systems but do not want to log out because of the temporary nature of their absences.
securityRequirements.title: Permit to manually lock session

securityRequirements.description: The system shall conceal information previously visible on the display with a publicly viewable image.
securityRequirements.note: Publicly viewable images can include static or dynamic images, for example, patterns used with screen savers, photographic images, solid colours, clock, battery life indicator, or a blank screen, with the additional caveat that none of the images convey sensitive information.
securityRequirements.title: Conceal information previously visible after session lock

securityRequirements.description: The information system shall prevent the use of input mechanisms (e.g. keyboard or mouse) when the session is locked while still displaying operational data on screen.
securityRequirements.note: This is needed for systems where data needs to be always displayed on screen (M&C workstations); which would be protected by a kind of transparent screen-saver when the session is locked.
securityRequirements.title: Permit the use of a "transparent" screen lock

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements define the information to be displayed when the screen is locked.
securityRequirements.title: Conceal information previously visible after session lock

securityRequirements.description: A�[shut out time delay] shall be enforced after a configurable [number of failed log-in attempts] before allowing a further log-in attempt.
securityRequirements.note:
Due to the potential for denial of service, automatic lockouts initiated by information systems are usually temporary and automatically release after a predetermined time period established by organizations. If a delay algorithm is selected, organizations may choose to employ different algorithms for different information system components based on the capabilities of those components. Responses to unsuccessful logon attempts may be implemented at both the operating system and the application levels.

For missions where availability is critical, the values ( [number of failed log-in attempts] and the�[shut out time delay]) can be set to soften the impact of this requirment (e.g set a high number of allowed attempts and a short shut out time delay).
securityRequirements.title: Enforce a lockout after failed log-in attempts

securityRequirements.note: The following requirement cover the session lock requirement.
securityRequirements.title: Session lock

securityRequirements.description: The system shall limit the maxium number concurrent sessions opened by different users.
securityRequirements.title: Limit concurrent sessions overall

securityRequirements.description: The system shall restrict the maximum number of concurrent sessions that belong to the same user.
securityRequirements.title: Limit concurrent sessions per user

securityRequirements.description:
The system shall be able to deny session establishment based on one or a combination of the following:
- The location of the user terminal,
- Time of day and day of week
- User ID
securityRequirements.title: Permit to deny unauthorised session establishments

securityRequirements.description: The system shall only allow the installation of [certificate authorities] for verification of the establishment of protected sessions.
securityRequirements.note: Reliance on certificate authorities (CAs) for the establishment of secure sessions includes, for example, the use of Secure Socket Layer (SSL) and/or Transport Layer Security (TLS) certificates. These certificates, after verification by the respective certificate authorities, facilitate the establishment of protected sessions between web clients and web servers.
securityRequirements.title: Only allow certificate authorities for verification of protected sessions

securityRequirements.description: The system shall generate a unique session identifier for each session with [randomness requirements] and recognizes only session identifiers that are system-generated.
securityRequirements.note: This curtails the ability of adversaries from reusing previously valid session IDs. Employing the concept of randomness in the generation of unique session identifiers helps to protect against brute-force attacks to determine future session identifiers.
securityRequirements.title: Session unique identifiers

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect the authenticity of communication sessions.
securityRequirements.note: This addresses communications protection at the session, versus packet level (e.g., sessions in service-oriented architectures providing web-based services) and establishes grounds for confidence at both ends of communications sessions in on-going identities of other parties and in the validity of information transmitted. Authenticity protection includes, for example, protecting against man-in-the-middle attacks/session hijacking and the insertion of false information into sessions.
securityRequirements.title: Protect authenticity of communication sessions

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover the establishment of sessions.
securityRequirements.title: Session establishment

securityRequirements.description:
This section specifies requirements for controlling the establishment of a user's session. Without any explicit restriction, it is applicable for both local and remote access.
- A session refers to the time frame between the user's login and logoff.
- A user could open a session locally on the workstation he is using; this is named a ?local access?.
- A user could open a session on a remote computer through the network; this is named a ?remote access?.
securityRequirements.title: Session

securityRequirements.description: Mutual system authentication, between parts of the system and any external systems, shall occur prior any data exchange.
securityRequirements.note: This is particularly important before the identification/authentication of a user.
securityRequirements.title: Mutually authenticate with external systems prior any exchange

securityRequirements.description: The system shall deny all flows not explicitly allowed with an external system.
securityRequirements.title: Deny not explicitly allowed flows between external systems

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce the access control policy between external systems.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce access control policy between external systems

securityRequirements.description: The system shall deny all flows not explicitly allowed between parts of the system.
securityRequirements.title: Deny not explicitly allowed flows between parts of a system

securityRequirements.description: Physically or logically separated parts of the system shall authenticate each other prior any exchange.
securityRequirements.title: Authenticate physically separated parts prior any exchange

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce the access control policy between (internal) part of a system.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce access control policy between (internal) parts of a system

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce a network access control policy to prevent the disclosure, modification, replay, loss of use of any data transmitted between systems.
securityRequirements.note: It shall not be possible to bypass this access control policy.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce network access control policies

securityRequirements.description: Boundary protection mechanisms shall be employed to separate information system components directly supporting missions and/or business functions.
securityRequirements.note: Such isolation limits unauthorized information flows among system components and also provides the opportunity to deploy greater levels of protection for selected components. Separating system components with boundary protection mechanisms provides the capability for increased protection of individual components and to more effectively control information flows between those components. This type of enhanced protection limits the potential harm from cyber-attacks and errors. The degree of separation provided varies depending upon the mechanisms chosen. Boundary protection mechanisms include, for example, routers, gateways, and firewalls separating system components into physically separate networks or sub-networks, cross-domain devices separating sub-networks, and encrypting information flows among system components using distinct encryption keys.
securityRequirements.title: Employ boundary protection for missions and business functions

securityRequirements.description: The system shall route internal communications traffic to external networks through authenticated proxy servers at managed interfaces.
securityRequirements.note: External networks are networks outside of organisational control. A proxy server is a server (i.e., information system or application) that acts as an intermediary for clients requesting information system resources (e.g., files, connections, web pages, or services) from other organizational servers. Client requests established through an initial connection to the proxy server are evaluated to manage complexity and to provide additional protection by limiting direct connectivity. Web content filtering devices are one of the most common proxy servers providing access to the Internet. Proxy servers support logging individual Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) sessions and blocking specific Uniform Resource Locators (URLs), domain names, and Internet Protocol (IP) addresses. Web proxies can be configured with organization-defined lists of authorized and unauthorized websites.
securityRequirements.title: Route outgoing traffic through authenticated proxies

securityRequirements.description: The system shall connect to external networks or information systems only through managed interfaces consisting of boundary protection devices arranged in accordance with an organisational security architecture.
securityRequirements.note: Managed interfaces include, for example, gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture (e.g., routers protecting firewalls or application gateways residing on protected sub networks). Sub networks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational information systems includes, for example, restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces and prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses. Organisations consider the shared nature of commercial telecommunications services in the implementation of security controls associated with the use of such services. Commercial telecommunications services are commonly based on network components and consolidated management systems shared by all attached commercial customers, and may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such transmission services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions.
securityRequirements.title: Connect to external networks only through managed interfaces

securityRequirements.description: The system shall fail securely in the event of an operational failure of a boundary protection device.
securityRequirements.note: Fail secure is a condition achieved by employing information system mechanisms to ensure that in the event of operational failures of boundary protection devices at managed interfaces (e.g., routers, firewalls, guards, and application gateways residing on protected sub networks commonly referred to as demilitarized zones), information systems do not enter into unsecure states where intended security properties no longer hold. Failures of boundary protection devices cannot lead to, or cause information external to the devices to enter the devices, nor can failures permit unauthorized information releases.
securityRequirements.title: Fail securely on boundary protection devices

securityRequirements.description: The system shall block both inbound and outbound communications traffic between communication clients that are independently configured by end users and external service providers.
securityRequirements.note: Communication clients independently configured by end users and external service providers include, for example, instant messaging clients. Traffic blocking does not apply to communication clients that are configured by organisations to perform authorised functions.
securityRequirements.title: Block communication from non-organisationally configured hosts

securityRequirements.description: The system shall, at managed interfaces, deny network communications traffic by default and allow network communications traffic by exception (i.e., deny all, permit by exception).
securityRequirements.note: This applies to both inbound and outbound network communications traffic. A deny-all, permit-by-exception network communications traffic policy ensures that only those connections which are essential and approved are allowed.
securityRequirements.title: Deny network traffic by default / allow by exception

securityRequirements.description: The system shall detect and deny outgoing communications traffic posing a threat to external information systems.
securityRequirements.note: Detecting outgoing communications traffic from internal actions that may pose threats to external information systems is sometimes termed extrusion detection. Extrusion detection at information system boundaries as part of managed interfaces includes the analysis of incoming and outgoing communications traffic searching for indications of internal threats to the security of external systems. Such threats include, for example, traffic indicative of denial of service attacks and traffic containing malicious code.
securityRequirements.title: Detect and audit outgoing threatening communication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall route all networked, privileged accesses through a dedicated, managed interface for purposes of access control and auditing.
securityRequirements.title: Route privileged network accesses

securityRequirements.description: The system shall only allow incoming communications from authorised sources routed to authorised destinations.
securityRequirements.note: This provides determinations that source and destination address pairs represent authorised/allowed communications. Such determinations can be based on several factors including, for example, the presence of source/destination address pairs in lists of authorised/allowed communications, the absence of address pairs in lists of unauthorised/disallowed pairs, or meeting more general rules for authorised/allowed source/destination pairs.
securityRequirements.title: Restrict incoming communication traffic

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prevent the discovery of specific system components composing a managed interface.
securityRequirements.note: This protects network addresses of information system components that are part of managed interfaces from discovery through common tools and techniques used to identify devices on networks. Network addresses are not available for discovery (e.g., network address not published or entered in domain name systems), requiring prior knowledge for access. Another obfuscation technique is to periodically change network addresses.
securityRequirements.title: Prevent discovery of components/devices

securityRequirements.description: The system shall, in conjunction with a remote device, prevent the device from simultaneously establishing non-remote connections with the system and communicating via some other connection to resources in external networks.
securityRequirements.note: This is implemented within remote devices (e.g., notebook computers) through configuration settings to disable split tunnelling in those devices, and by preventing those configuration settings from being readily configurable by users. This control enhancement is implemented within the information system by the detection of split tunnelling (or of configuration settings that allow split tunnelling) in the remote device, and by prohibiting the connection if the remote device is using split tunnelling. Split tunnelling might be desirable by remote users to communicate with local information system resources such as printers/file servers. However, split tunnelling would in effect allow unauthorized external connections, making the system more vulnerable to attack and to exfiltration of organizational information. The use of VPNs for remote connections, when adequately provisioned with appropriate security controls, may provide the organization with sufficient assurance that it can effectively treat such connections as non-remote connections from the confidentiality and integrity perspective. VPNs thus provide a means for allowing non-remote communications paths from remote devices. The use of an adequately provisioned VPN does not eliminate the need for preventing split tunnelling.
securityRequirements.title: Prevent split tunnelling with remote devices

securityRequirements.description: The number of external network connections to the information system shall be limited and kept to a minimum and documented in the ICD.
securityRequirements.note: Limiting the number of external network connections facilitates more comprehensive monitoring of inbound and outbound communications traffic. The Trusted Internet Connection (TIC) initiative is an example of limiting the number of external network connections.
securityRequirements.title: Limit the number of external network connections

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce the information flow control rules (e.g. explicitely accept or deny flows) based on security attributes.
securityRequirements.title: Illicit information flow management

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prevent and ensure that no illicit information flows exist to circumvent.
securityRequirements.note:
Illicit information flows shall have been identified in the information flow control policies.
If illicit information flows cannot be avoided, they shall be limited and monitored.
securityRequirements.title: Use security attributes

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce a flow control policy to prevent the disclosure, modification, replay, loss of use of any data transmitted between separated parts of the system.
securityRequirements.note: It shall not be possible to bypass these flow control policy.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce information flow control policies between parts of a system

securityRequirements.description: The system shall monitor and control communications at the external boundary of the system and at key internal boundaries within the system
securityRequirements.note: Managed interfaces include, for example, gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture (e.g., routers protecting firewalls or application gateways residing on protected sub networks). Sub networks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational information systems includes, for example, restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces and prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses. Organisations consider the shared nature of commercial telecommunications services in the implementation of security controls associated with the use of such services. Commercial telecommunications services are commonly based on network components and consolidated management systems shared by all attached commercial customers, and may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such transmission services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions.
securityRequirements.title: Monitor and control external and internal boundaries

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce adherence to protocol formats.
securityRequirements.note: Information system components that enforce protocol formats include, for example, deep packet inspection firewalls and XML gateways. Such system components verify adherence to protocol formats/specifications (e.g., IEEE) at the application layer and identify significant vulnerabilities that cannot be detected by devices operating at the network or transport layers.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce adherence to protocol formats

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement sub networks for publicly accessible system components that are physically or logically separated from internal organisational networks.
securityRequirements.note: Managed interfaces include, for example, gateways, routers, firewalls, guards, or encrypted tunnels implemented within a security architecture (e.g., routers protecting firewalls or application gateways residing on protected sub networks). Sub networks that are physically or logically separated from internal networks are referred to as demilitarized zones or DMZs. Restricting or prohibiting interfaces within organizational information systems includes, for example, restricting external web traffic to designated web servers within managed interfaces and prohibiting external traffic that appears to be spoofing internal addresses. Organisations consider the shared nature of commercial telecommunications services in the implementation of security controls associated with the use of such services. Commercial telecommunications services are commonly based on network components and consolidated management systems shared by all attached commercial customers, and may also include third party-provided access lines and other service elements. Such transmission services may represent sources of increased risk despite contract security provisions.
securityRequirements.title: Implement sub networks for publicly accessible systems

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement/use separate network addresses (i.e., different subnets) to connect to systems in different security domains.
securityRequirements.note: Decomposition of information systems into subnets helps to provide the appropriate level of protection for network connections to different security domains containing information with different security categories or classification levels.
securityRequirements.title: Separate different security domains in separate subnets

securityRequirements.description: The system shall disable feedback to senders on protocol format validation failure.
securityRequirements.note: Disabling feedback to senders when there is a failure in protocol validation format prevents adversaries from obtaining information which would otherwise be unavailable.
securityRequirements.title: Disable sender feedback on protocol validation failures

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide the capability to dynamically isolate/segregate information system components from other components of the system.
securityRequirements.note: The capability to dynamically isolate or segregate certain internal components of organizational information systems is useful when it is necessary to partition or separate certain components of dubious origin from those components possessing greater trustworthiness. Component isolation reduces the attack surface of organizational information systems. Isolation of selected information system components is also a means of limiting the damage from successful cyber-attacks when those attacks occur.
securityRequirements.title: Permit to dynamically isolate/segregate system components

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement network access hardening steps.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure Access Hardening

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover the access control of the network.
securityRequirements.title: Network

securityRequirements.description: The system shall separate anonymous from authenticated resources.
securityRequirements.note: Partition resources by anonymous, identified and��authenticated users.
securityRequirements.title: Separate anonymous from authenticated resources

securityRequirements.description: Unnecessary access to databases or other expensive resources shall be avoided for non-privileged users.
securityRequirements.title: Avoid unnecessary access for non-privileged users

securityRequirements.description: The system shall restrict access to test data.
securityRequirements.title: Restrict access to test data

securityRequirements.description: When dealing with privileges in a system, consider the concept of "least privilege", which is, allowing only authorized accesses for users or processes which are necessary to accomplish the assigned tasks.
securityRequirements.title: Base privileges in the system on "least privilege" concept

securityRequirements.description: Only needed access, ports and other configurations shall be configured: all unnecessary�configurations shall be deleted
securityRequirements.title: Configure only needed access

securityRequirements.description: The access control policy to system data, objects or operation shall be based only on roles, not on the identification of the users.
securityRequirements.title: Base system access on only on roles

securityRequirements.description: The system shall separate user functionality (including user interface services) from information system management functionality.
securityRequirements.note: Information system management functionality includes, for example, functions necessary to administer databases, network components, workstations, or servers, and typically requires privileged user access. The separation of user functionality from information system management functionality is either physical or logical. Organizations implement separation of system management-related functionality from user functionality by using different computers, different central processing units, different instances of operating systems, different network addresses, virtualization techniques, or combinations of these or other methods, as appropriate. This type of separation includes, for example, web administrative interfaces that use separate authentication methods for users of any other information system resources. Separation of system and user functionality may include isolating administrative interfaces on different domains and with additional access controls.
securityRequirements.title: Separate user from management functionalities

securityRequirements.description: Access to executable files shall be validated by the system.
securityRequirements.note: E.g. access path shall not include the current directory, shall be limited to trusted software, shall be limited according to the user's role ?
securityRequirements.title: Validate access to executable files

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use dual authorisations mechanisms to execute [specific commands/actions].
securityRequirements.note: Dual authorisation mechanisms require the approval of two authorized individuals in order to execute. Organisations do not require dual authorization mechanisms when immediate responses are necessary to ensure public and environmental safety.
securityRequirements.title: Use dual authorisation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce the implementation of the [System Access Control Policy] to system appliances, objects, operation and data.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce system access control policies

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover the access control to the system.
securityRequirements.title: System

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use tamperproof access control mechanisms.
securityRequirements.note: The tamperproof property of the access control mechanism prevents adversaries from compromising the functioning of the mechanism. This prevents adversaries from bypassing the mechanism and hence violating the security policy.
securityRequirements.title: Use tamperproof access control mechanisms

securityRequirements.description: The user ID shall not give any indication of the real user name.
securityRequirements.note: This is intended to preserve a user anonimity. This ensure that nobody is unable to determine the real user name bound to the user ID.
securityRequirements.title: Avoid personnal information via user ID

securityRequirements.description: The user ID shall not give any indication of the user's privilege level.
securityRequirements.title: Avoid role information disclosure via user ID

securityRequirements.description: The user ID used to identify a user in the system shall be unique.
securityRequirements.title: Use unique user ID

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use challenge-response tests to idendify whether or not the user is human.
securityRequirements.note: This applies mostly for services available to web users. Challenge-response systems, widely known as CAPTCHAs (Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart), permit to restrict the use of automatic scripts for specific features (e.g. browsing, registering).
securityRequirements.title: Use human identification challenges

securityRequirements.description: The system shall detect and prevent the use of authentication data that has been copied or forged by any user.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce an unforgeable authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to dynamically associate authenticators with identifiers.
securityRequirements.note: In contrast to conventional approaches to identification which presume static accounts for preregistered users, many distributed information systems including, for example, service-oriented architectures, rely on establishing identities at run time for entities that were previously unknown. In these situations, organisations anticipate and provision for the dynamic association of authenticators with identities. Pre-established trust relationships and mechanisms with appropriate authorities to validate identities and related credentials are essential.
securityRequirements.title: Permit dynamic authentication association

securityRequirements.description: Passwords shall never be transmitted in clear text and their encryption shall be done using appropriate algorithms.
securityRequirements.note: This does not apply when passwords are used to unlock hardware authenticators (e.g., Personal Identity Verification cards). Encrypted representations of passwords include, for example, encrypted versions of passwords and one-way cryptographic hashes of passwords.
securityRequirements.title: Do not transmit passwords in clear text

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that passwords have a minimal length.
securityRequirements.note: This ensures that effort to access the account or services is coherent with the strength of the authentication mechanism and the sensitivity of the application and data to protect.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure password minimal length

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that passwords have a minimum complexity.
securityRequirements.note: This ensures that effort to access the account or services is coherent with the strength of the authentication mechanism and the sensitivity of the application and data to protect.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure password minimal complexity

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that passwords are changed regularly.
securityRequirements.note: This requirement may be enforced through organisational verification (e.g. for the users to follow security directives) although technical means are strongly recommended (e.g. a proper configuration of the operating system).
securityRequirements.title: Ensure regular password renewal

securityRequirements.description: The system shall force users to change temporary password (i.e. re-initialised by the Security Administrator) when they first log-on.
securityRequirements.title: Force to change temporary password

securityRequirements.description: It shall be possible to define a number of previous passwords that may not be re-used
securityRequirements.title: Password re-use

securityRequirements.note: Following requirements ensure a proper lifecycle of passwords in the system.
securityRequirements.title: Password lifecycle

securityRequirements.description: Passwords shall follow the definitions in the "ESACERT Security Guidelines ? Recommendations for Password usage" password best practices.
securityRequirements.title: Follow password guidelines

securityRequirements.description: Passwords stored by the system shall be stored using a secure one-way encryption algorithm.
securityRequirements.note:
This shall apply to online storage as well as to any kind of offline storage (e.g. on access control media).
Note that if passwords, pin codes and the like are stored on media, the media are considered part of the system.
As an example, assuming that the authentication process relies on a password-based solution, the system shall store the passwords of the users encrypted.
securityRequirements.title: Store password securely

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use password based authentication.
securityRequirements.note:
IMPORTANT: Solely relying on password based authentication shall only be used carefully in specific advised cases

A number of factors affect the security of a system which relies on passwords for authentication. These factors include the composition, length, lifetime, source, ownership, distribution, storage, entry, transmission, and authentication period of the passwords.

Policies and procedures have been developed for the management of password-only authentication techniques. However, these techniques are sometimes difficult to implement effectively in real-world situations. Some of the factors which influence the security of a password system may be beyond the control of those responsible for managing the system. During the development of a computer system, it is common practice for the system developers to use master passwords which provide total control over the system for debugging purposes. These passwords are sometimes left in the product either inadvertently or intentionally, when the system goes into production. When this is done intentionally, it provides the developer with a convenient "back door" entry into the customer's system which facilitates product support and maintenance. However, this is a dangerous practice because an intruder may be able to gain complete control over the system by leaking the developer's password. In addition, the customer may not wish to trust the manufacturer with this level of control over a system after it is installed at the customer's site. Customers should verify that passwords used by the manufacturer during system development and installation have been removed before the system is used.

The, password problem is multiplied when users access remote computing resources through a network. Because it is difficult to control physical access to remote terminals, it is possible for an attacker to make repeated attempts to guess passwords on host computers connected to the network. In addition, passwords are often transmitted to a remote computer to authenticate the user. Transmitting static passwords over a network in plaintext form can drastically increase the opportunities for an attacker to capture them directly from the communications line, or from a computer which is acting as an intermediate node in the transmission process. There have been numerous well-publicized cases of intruders breaking into computer systems by guessing or stealing passwords.

Authentication which relies solely on passwords has often failed to provide adequate protection for computer systems for a number of reasons. If users are allowed to make up their own passwords, they tend to choose ones which are easy to remember, and therefore easy to guess. If passwords are generated from a random combination of characters, users often write them down because they are difficult to remember. Systems which use only passwords for authentication should provide strong mechanisms for controlling the generation, distribution, and use of system passwords. Password systems can be effective if managed properly, but this is seldom the case. Advances in security technology provide a number of alternative authentication methods which can be used alone or in combination with passwords to improve the security of an access control system.
securityRequirements.title: Password based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a TAN card as static password token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note:
A Transaction authentication number, TAN or T.A.N. is to provide a form of single use one-time passwords. TANs should only be used as a second layer of security additional to other authentication methods (i.e. traditional password authentication).
TAN card usually contain a series of number/letters from which the user is requested a specific and different subset at each connection.
securityRequirements.title: TAN Cards

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a static password token method for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note:
The advantage of this technique is that there is no synchronization needed with a server or the system itself. The information is set once and for all at the moment where the token is issued.
The security of this method is however limited by the size of the password on the token, thus it makes it more vulnerable to guessing and replay attacks compared to synchronous or challenge-response tokens.
securityRequirements.title: Static password token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a USB device as challenge-response token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.title: USB device

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a smart-card as challenge-response token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note: Smart card have a cryptographic ship containing a pair of private/public key that permits to send challenge.
securityRequirements.title: Smartcard token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a RFID device as challenge-response token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.title: RFID token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a connected challenge-response token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note: Such a token must be physically connected to the system and must respond successfully to a specific challenge, thereby authenticating the user.
securityRequirements.title: Connected challenge-response token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use one-time password generator device token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note:
Those devices, also known as Hand Held Password Generators, are microprocessor based authentication tokens which do not require a physical connection to host systems. These devices communicate directly with human users through an on-board display and some form of keypad. Users relay authentication data, such as passwords or encrypted challenges, between tokens and host systems manually.

One time password generators create a sequence of passwords which are synchronized in some manner with host systems. Each password is only valid for one authentication, and so cannot be recorded and replayed to gain access. Synchronization is often based on a secret initial seed value which is permuted at specific time intervals, or possibly each time an authentication event occurs. Without knowledge of the secret value and the number of times it has been permuted, an observer cannot predict the next password in the sequence even if one or more previous passwords are known. Some password generators require the user to enter a PIN via the on-board keypad before the device will generate a password.

Challenge response calculators accept a random challenge from the host system, which is read by the user and entered through the calculator's keypad. The calculator then encrypts the challenge with a secret cryptographic key and displays the result. The user enters the encrypted challenge on the host keyboard, and the host verifies the encryption. This process requires each participant in the authentication process to possess a copy of the secret cryptographic key. Challenge response calculators typically require users to enter a PIN before executing the authentication exchange with a host system.

Authentication tokens that do not require an electronic interface for communications with host systems can be used in a wide range of environments, since all general purpose computer terminals can display random challenges and accept passwords or encrypted challenges as keyboard input. One time password generators and challenge response calculators eliminate the cost of the special purpose interfaces required by other types of tokens.
securityRequirements.title: One-time password device token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide a challenge-response token via a physically and logically separated communication channel and device for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note: This can be done by sending a SMS to a specific, pre-configured (i.e. not modifiable at time of login), number that contains a challenge that the user must type manually in the login interface.
securityRequirements.title: Alternate communication channel token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a password generator software token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note:
This another type of Hand Held Password Generators that instead of being based on a specific device are implemented as a software that runs on a hand held device such as a smartphone (it is important that the token can be easily stay physically with the user).
Same as for "One-time password device tokens", software tokens do not require a physical or any connection to host systems, the software communicate directly with human users through simple interface. Users relay authentication data, such as passwords or encrypted challenges, between tokens and host systems manually.
securityRequirements.title: Password generator software token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a not-connected synchronous dynamic password token for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note: This is any password that is generated at an action of the user (e.g. pushing a button), on a disconnected device, where the resulting password is synchronised with the server (i.e. by time). The authentication is successful if the password "predicted" at the server side is the same as the one given by the disconnected device.
securityRequirements.title: Disconnected synchronous dynamic password token

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use authentication tokens to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.note:
The identity of a human user can be proven by requiring the user to demonstrate possession of a physical object which is unique to that user, or to a group of users. Objects used for this it purpose are known as authentication tokens. Since the uniqueness of the information stored on an authentication token is responsible for proving the identity of its bearer to the host system, the information must be protected against duplication or theft. Advanced tokens usually contain a microprocessor and semiconductor memory, and support sophisticated authentication protocols which provide a high level of security.

From a security standpoint, the strength of token based authentication lies in the fact that the device containing the information which verifies the identity of the user is portable. Therefore, the authentication information can be kept in the user's possession. The greatest threat to the security of this type of system is the possibility that an attacker could steal a valid token in order to pose as an authorized user. A sophisticated attacker might also be able to counterfeit a token. These threats can be reduced by requiring the user to submit a password or PIN when the token is used for authentication. There should be a limit to the number of consecutive incorrect PIN submissions. Without the password, a stolen or counterfeited token would not allow an attacker to gain access to the system. This can significantly increase the level of assurance since a user's identity is verified based on something the user knows in addition to possession of the token. Compromise of one user's token should only compromise that user, not the entire system. Use of tokens with cryptographic capabilities can contribute greatly to the security of an authentication system. In addition, the use of passwords or PINs in combination with authentication tokens is recommended for applications where this approach is practical.

The type of authentication token selected for a particular application will depend on a number of factors.
securityRequirements.title: Token based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a voice recognition authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Voice based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a facial recognition authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Facial recognition based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a fingerprint authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Fingerprint based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a Iris pattern recognition authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Iris pattern based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a hand geometry recognition authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Hand geometry based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a sgnature dynamics regonition authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Signature dynamics based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a retinal authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Retinal based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a vascular pattern recognition authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: Vascular pattern based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a biometric authentication system/method to authenticate users.
securityRequirements.note:
Certain physical features of the human body are relatively unique from individual to individual. Facial photographs and fingerprints have long been used for personal identification, particularly by law enforcement agencies. Biometric authentication is the measurement of a unique biological feature used to verify the claimed identity of an individual through automated means. The biometric authentication mechanism will strive to measure a unique biological feature to the degree that only one person may be authenticated as a specific user. The biological feature may be based on a physiological or behavioural characteristic. The physiological characteristics measure a physical feature such as a fingerprint or face. The behavioural characteristics measure your reaction or response such as your signature or voice. The most used biometrics are fingerprint, retinal and voice authentication devices.
References: FIPS Publication 201
securityRequirements.title: Biometric based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prohibit the use of cached authenticators after [cache expiration time period].
securityRequirements.title: Prohibit the use of cached authenticators after time period

securityRequirements.note:
The following requirement list the possible authentication methods that can be used.
In case of multi-factor authentication, at least two of the following methods shall be selected.
securityRequirements.title: Authentication types

securityRequirements.description: The system shall re-authenticate the user under [specific conditions].
securityRequirements.title: Re-authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use multiple-factor authentication for the authentication of users in the system.
securityRequirements.note: That is, the system shall base authentication on at least two different authentication techniques (e.g. password based + token based).
securityRequirements.title: Multi-factor authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use single-factor authentication for the authentication of users in the system.
securityRequirements.title: Single-factor authentication

securityRequirements.description: When authentication mechanisms are based on secrets, it shall be ensured that the secrets are of appropriate strength.
securityRequirements.note:
The authentication process may rely on a wide range of mechanisms, some of them requiring additional data only known by the user himself.
This personal data are called secrets; it could be dongle, password, etc.
NB.: Secrets are not mandatory. Biometric data (eyes prints or fingerprints) could now be used to recognised users.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure strength of secrets

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement multifactor authentication for remote access to privileged accounts such that one of the factors is provided by a device separate from the system gaining access and the device meets strength mechanism requirements.
securityRequirements.title: Use a separate device for remote access to privileged accounts

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement multifactor authentication for remote access to non-privileged accounts such that one of the factors is provided by a device separate from the system gaining access and the device meets strength mechanism requirements.
securityRequirements.title: Use a separate device for remote access to non-privileged accounts

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement multifactor authentication for remote access.
securityRequirements.title: Use a separate device for remote access

securityRequirements.description: The system shall employ suitable authentication techniques to uniquely authenticate users.
securityRequirements.title: User authentication

securityRequirements.description: Any user shall be identified by a unique reference / identifier. An appropriate authentication technique shall be implemented to bind a user with his identifier.
securityRequirements.note: Access control shall apply at several levels. It is important to restrict access to the workstation or server and application's access needs also to be submitted to their own identification and authentication process. Consequently, the requirement shall apply to workstations and to critical applications as well.
securityRequirements.title: Identification and authentication of users

securityRequirements.description: The system shall detect when a number of unsuccessful authentication attempts related to a user since the last successful authentication occurred. The number of unsuccessful authentication attempts shall be configurable.
securityRequirements.note: This prevents an attacker to scan all possible passwords for breaking the access control mechanism. They are mandatory to protect from attacks driven by people around authorised user.
securityRequirements.title: Detect unsuccessful log-in tentative

securityRequirements.description: Upon successful session establishment, the system shall display to the user the date, time and location of the last unsuccessful attempt of session establishment and the number of unsuccessful attempts since the last successful session establishment.
securityRequirements.title: Display last unsuccessful session

securityRequirements.description: Upon successful session establishment, the system shall display to the user the date, time and location of the last successful session establishment.
securityRequirements.note: This is intended to cover both traditional logons to information systems and accesses to systems that occur in other types of architectural configurations (e.g., service oriented architectures).
securityRequirements.title: Display last successful session

securityRequirements.description: The system shall not erase the access history from the user interface without giving the user the opportunity to review the information.
securityRequirements.title: Display access history

securityRequirements.description: Before the user log-on, the system shall display an advisory warning message regarding unauthorised use of the system.
securityRequirements.note:
For externally accessible systems, users shall be deterred from using information processing facilities for unauthorized purposes.
The information system shall display a notification message or banner about the applicable laws, regulations and policies of usage before granting access to the system. An explicit approval by the user is necessary.
The information system shall: a. Display an approved system use notification message or banner before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance and states that:
a. Display an approved system use notification message or banner before granting access to the system that provides privacy and security notices consistent with applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, regulations, standards, and guidance and states that:
- Users are accessing a restricted (e.g. Governmental) information system;
- Information system usage may be monitored, recorded, and subject to audit;
- Unauthorized use of the information system is prohibited and subject to criminal and civil penalties; and
- Use of the information system indicates consent to monitoring and recording;
b. Retain the notification message or banner on the screen until users take explicit actions to log on to or further access the information system; and
c. For publicly accessible systems:
- Display the system use information [Assignment: organization-defined conditions], before granting further access;
- Display references, if any, to monitoring, recording, or auditing that are consistent with privacy accommodations for such systems that generally prohibit those activities; and
- Include in the notice given to public users of the information system, a description of the authorized uses of the system
System use notifications can be implemented using warning banners displayed when individuals log in to information systems. System use notifications are only used for access via interactive login interfaces with human users and are not required when interactive login interfaces do not exist.
securityRequirements.title: Display warning message

securityRequirements.description:
Only identification and authentication data fields required for log-on purposes shall be displayed except for network services/applications running under the Monitoring System role:
For these, it shall be allowed to display/output the respective monitoring information as well.
securityRequirements.title: Display minimal information with monitoring exception

securityRequirements.description: Only identification and authentication data fields required for log-on purposes shall be displayed for all roles and users.
securityRequirements.title: Display minimal information

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about the display of log-on information.
securityRequirements.title: Log-on display restrictions

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure the implementation of a secure user log-on process.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure secure log-on

securityRequirements.description: In cases where a Single-Sign On Solution would link information from different security classification zones, a separation mechanism shall be established to avoid compromising or leaking of information.
securityRequirements.note: Single sign-on enables users to log in once and gain access to multiple information system resources without additional interactive logins. Organisations balance the operational efficiencies provided by single sign-on capabilities with the increased risk from disclosures of single authenticators providing access to multiple system resources.
securityRequirements.title: Separate single-sign on solutions on between zones

securityRequirements.description: When the [number of unsuccessful authentication attempts] has been reached or exceeded, the system shall disable the access to the user for a certain time. This time shall be configurable.
securityRequirements.note:
This is prevents an attacker to scan all possible passwords for breaking the access control mechanism. They are mandatory to protect from attacks driven by people around authorised user.
This control applies regardless of whether the logon occurs via a local or network connection. Due to the potential for denial of service, automatic lockouts initiated by information systems are usually temporary and automatically release after a predetermined time period established by organizations. If a delay algorithm is selected, organizations may choose to employ different algorithms for different information system components based on the capabilities of those components. Responses to unsuccessful login attempts may be implemented at both the operating system and the application levels.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce user deactivation after failed attempts

securityRequirements.description: The system shall automatically disable inactive accounts after a [pre-defined time period].
securityRequirements.note:
Such measures can be taken when an account is inactive during an considerable long time to avoid the persistence of unused/old accounts.
Note: Disable here means deactivation and not deletion.
securityRequirements.title: Automatically disable inactive accounts

securityRequirements.description: The system shall permit to disable and lock user accounts.
securityRequirements.title: User deactivation/lock

securityRequirements.description: The system shall assign the least privileged role to a user by default when no other indication is available (e.g. explicit choice made by the user).
securityRequirements.note: For example, on a linux system, a user be a regular user but also an administrator of the machine. When that user logs in, he should not be automatically assigned all privileges when he doesn't actually need to oeprate as root on the machine. Therefore, in that example, he should only be assigned to the "regular user" role by default, until he makes an explicit action to obtain the root privileges.
securityRequirements.title: Assign the lowest privilege role by default

securityRequirements.description: High privileged accounts shall be able to list all current sessions. They shall also be able to terminate a specific one.
securityRequirements.title: List and close sessions

securityRequirements.description: The system shall permit the user to select the role, among those assigned to that user, with which he wants to operate.
securityRequirements.title: Permit user role selection at login

securityRequirements.description: After a successful identification and authentication, the system shall assign to the users one or more predefined roles that govern their access to the system objects and operations.
securityRequirements.note: This requirement simplifies the management of privileges. Only assignments of role to users have to be updated. Assignment of role to system objects and operation is made during the system development. Initial assignment and evolution shall not induce security breaches. It not only applies to Operating Systems objects but also to application operations. It enables a more precise use of the data than grant or denial access. In any case the actions are imputable to a well-defined user.
securityRequirements.title: Assign roles to users

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a centralised user rights and roles management system.
securityRequirements.title: Use a central user rights and roles management

securityRequirements.description: The system shall allow handover of a working environment between users of the same role or between roles defined by the [allowed role transitions].
securityRequirements.note:
This is needed e.g. to facilitate session handover between operator shifts without application restart.
This is particularly important for critical application requiring running continuously.
securityRequirements.title: Permit handover between roles

securityRequirements.description: The system shall allow some��[unauthenticated-actions] on behalf of the user to be performed before the user is authenticated.
securityRequirements.note: In some cases, several actions before authentication can be defined that permit users to execute several "emergency" or "recovery" actions. Such actions could be for example: trigger the password recovery procedure, notify a problem to the appropriate authority.
securityRequirements.title: Permit "emergency" actions of unauthenticated user

securityRequirements.description: The system shall require each user to be successfully authenticated before allowing any actions on behalf of that user.
securityRequirements.title: User authentication before any action

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about the actions which can be performed before authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Unauthenticated user rights

securityRequirements.note: The following requirement concern the management of roles within the system.
securityRequirements.title: Roles management

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover the access control of the user.
securityRequirements.title: User

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover security around access control of users to the system/software.
securityRequirements.title: Access control

securityRequirements.description: A suite of self-tests shall be run (e.g. during initial start-up, periodically during normal operation, at the request of the authorised user) to demonstrate the correct operation of itself.
securityRequirements.note:
Actions should be taken as the result of self-testing.
The corruption of security data, functions (including the one performing tests) should be also detected
securityRequirements.title: Perform self-test

securityRequirements.description: The system shall permit the rollback of all the operations.
securityRequirements.note: The rollback operation involves undoing the last operation or a series of operations, bounded by some limit, such as a period of time, and return to a previous known state. Rollback provides the ability to undo the effects of an operation or series of operations to preserve the integrity of the user data.
securityRequirements.title: Provide rollback operations

securityRequirements.description: The system shall check the size of all dynamic-size data against the allocated buffer size.
securityRequirements.note: A buffer overflow condition exists when a program attempts to put more data in a buffer than it can hold or when a program attempts to put data in a memory area past a buffer. In this case, a buffer is a sequential section of memory allocated to contain anything from a character string to an array of integers.
securityRequirements.title: Check data size to protect against bufferovervflows

securityRequirements.description: The system shall check the value of all array indexes against array boundaries.
securityRequirements.title: Check indexes

securityRequirements.description: The system shall maintain the confidentiality and integrity of information during preparation for transmission and during reception.
securityRequirements.note: Information can be either unintentionally or maliciously disclosed or modified during preparation for transmission or during reception including, for example, during aggregation, at protocol transformation points, and during packing/unpacking. These unauthorized disclosures or modifications compromise the confidentiality or integrity of the information.
securityRequirements.title: Protect information during pre/post transmission handling

securityRequirements.description: Server side validation shall always be performed for sensitive information. Never rely on client-side validation.
securityRequirements.title: Perform server side data validation

securityRequirements.description: The plausibility of data exchanged across different levels of security and/or between internal and external areas shall be checked according to the respective definitions of the data flows.
securityRequirements.title: Check data flow exchange plausibility

securityRequirements.description: Internal controls shall be implemented to identify any processing issues and malicious deliberate acts. Such controls should be settled to avoid any potential frauds.
securityRequirements.title: Management of the software internal operations

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement mechanisms that allow detection of, prevention of and recovery from integrity loss.
securityRequirements.note: This requirement reminds that all application software shall implement specific requirements in term of integrity. This includes specific data that are stored in databases, short term data in memory that may be protected from software bugs, data transmitted to external systems where external communication protection is not sufficient (e.g. satellite).
securityRequirements.title: Handle integrity loss

securityRequirements.description: Integrity checks shall rely on cryptographic Message Authentication Code (MAC).
securityRequirements.title: Rely on MAC for integrity checks

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about maintaining the integrity of information.
securityRequirements.title: Integrity checks

securityRequirements.description: User supplied files or filenames taken from the user shall be checked for legitimate purposes.
