securityRequirements.note: Any file provided by a user of any priviledges shall be checked against its content (i.e. content of the file shall match with the type(extension) of the file), its checksum (if any comparable source is available) and if the file type and content matches with the expected type and content (e.g. a program request a Word document, then only Word files with a valid Word content should be accepted) based on the current context of the system (e.g. is this user permitted to submit this type of file using this system in the current context?). The current context of the system, defines both, the files that should be accepted and from whom (which user/role) they can be accepted.
securityRequirements.title: Check user supplied files

securityRequirements.description:
Custom random tokens shall be inserted into every form, URL and HTTP request: these tokens shall be unique to that particular function or page for that user, or simply unique to the overall session.
Then the system shall check to see if the valid session token (and the parameters within the HTTP request) correspond. Next, the system shall take the session token and validate that it is associated with the user ID or requested account.
securityRequirements.note: If and only if the system can validate the authorization and destinations of parameters independently, should request and parameters be operated.
securityRequirements.title: Insert and check random tokens

securityRequirements.description: The system shall test all data received from an internal and external system before processing it in order to check compliance with the interface definition.
securityRequirements.note: The test shall be tailored according to the sensitivity of the system objects and operations being accessed and real time constrains.
securityRequirements.title: Check compliance of any received data before processing it

securityRequirements.description: Any input to software shall be validated to ensure that the software operates safe, clean and appropriated data.
securityRequirements.note: Validations such as length, interval value, etc. are especially important for data received from an un-trusted part of the system or an external source.
securityRequirements.title: Input validation

securityRequirements.description: A centralized approach for validation shall be considered (e.g. using common validation and filtering code in shared libraries). This ensures that the validation rules are applied consistently.
securityRequirements.title: Centralize validation approach

securityRequirements.description: Any output from a software shall be validated and sanitized to ensure that further operations performed on this data (e.g. storage) is correct, safe and appropriate.
securityRequirements.note:
This requirement means that data shall be verified before being sent out to minimize security breaches, e.g.. a string input through a MMI and sent to a shell.
This requirement is especially important to counter security breaches of third party programs. This reduces the use of these programs to known and tested vulnerabilities.
securityRequirements.title: Output validation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall behave in a predictable and documented manner that reflects organisational and system objectives when invalid inputs/outputs are received/sent.
securityRequirements.note: A common vulnerability in organisational information systems is unpredictable behaviour when invalid inputs are received. This control enhancement ensures that there is predictable behaviour in the face of invalid inputs by specifying information system responses that facilitate transitioning the system to known states without adverse, unintended side effects.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure a predictable behaviour on invalid inputs/outputs

securityRequirements.description: A whitelist approach for only accepting characters like a-z/A-Z/0-9/ or other safe special characters shall be defined and used.
securityRequirements.note: These kind of approach is recommended if there is no finite list of values available. The validation is then done by using regular expressions.
securityRequirements.title: Define and use a whitelist

securityRequirements.description: All XML messages shall be validated via XML Schema validation.
securityRequirements.title: Check XML messages

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use cryprographic controls for validating data integrity of output/input data.
securityRequirements.title: Use cryptographic controls to validate data integrity

securityRequirements.description: The system shall perform input and output data validation.
securityRequirements.note: Checking the valid syntax and semantics of information system inputs and outputs (e.g., character set, length, numerical range, and acceptable values) verifies that inputs and outputs match specified definitions for format and content. Software applications typically follow well-defined protocols that use structured messages (i.e., commands or queries) to communicate between software modules or system components. Structured messages can contain raw or unstructured data interspersed with metadata or control information. If software applications use attacker-supplied inputs to construct structured messages without properly encoding such messages, then the attacker could insert malicious commands or special characters that can cause the data to be interpreted as control information or metadata. Consequently, the module or component that receives the tainted output will perform the wrong operations or otherwise interpret the data incorrectly. Pre-screening inputs and outputs prior to passing to interpreters prevents the content from being unintentionally interpreted as commands. Input and output validation helps to ensure accurate and correct inputs/outputs and prevent attacks such as cross-site scripting and a variety of injection attacks.
securityRequirements.title: Input and output data validation

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover security on processing and validation of incoming or outgoing data.
securityRequirements.title: Processing / Data validation

securityRequirements.description: [Important-records] shall be protected from loss, destruction and falsification.
securityRequirements.title: Protection of records

securityRequirements.description: Only strong encryption and decryption algorithms shall be used for the data stored on disks : custom cryptographic algorithms shall not be implemented.
securityRequirements.note:
Use approved public key cryptographic algorithms like RSA, AES.
Use strong algorithms asSHA256 or better.
Generate strong cryptographic keys with minimum of 128bit key length and use strong random number generators for defining key.
securityRequirements.title: Use strong encryption for data stored on the disk

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement mechanisms that detect integrity loss of backup files.
securityRequirements.title: Check integrity of backup files

securityRequirements.description: Pages containing sensitive information shall not be cached by user's browsers.
securityRequirements.title: Disable client side caching pages

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that any data contained in a resource is not available when the resource is de-allocated from one object and reallocated to a different object.
securityRequirements.note: Protections are required for any data contained in a resource that has been logically deleted or released, but may still be present within the resource which in turn may be re-allocated to another object.
securityRequirements.title: Protect residual information

securityRequirements.description: Test text
securityRequirements.note: Test Comment
securityRequirements.title: Test

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement protections against data harvesting and data mining for data storage objects.
securityRequirements.note: Data storage objects include, for example, databases, database records, and database fields. Data mining and data harvesting techniques include, for example, limiting the types of responses provided to database queries or limiting the number or frequency of database queries to increase the work factor required to determine the contents of databases. This control can also be employed by organizations to reduce the effectiveness of information harvesting from social networking sites, thus, limiting the amount of information that can be obtained from those sites.
securityRequirements.title: Protect against data mining and harvesting

securityRequirements.description: Unauthorised information disclosure shall be prevented.
securityRequirements.title: Avoid information leakage of stored information

securityRequirements.description: Sensitive data shall be stored in non-swappable memory only.
securityRequirements.title: Store sensitive data in non-swappable memory

securityRequirements.description: Memory space dedicated to sensitive data shall be erased before and after use.
securityRequirements.title: Erase memory space dedicated to sensitive data

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are security controls about information storage.
securityRequirements.title: Storage of information

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement cryptographic mechanisms to authenticate software prior to installation.
securityRequirements.note:
Cryptographic authentication includes, for example, verifying that software or firmware components have been digitally signed using certificates recognized and approved by organizations. Code signing is an effective method to protect against malicious code.
Authentication of code relies on the availability ceritificates (e.g. Message Authentication Codes), which permit to verify, by comparing the certificate with the calculated signature,�the integrity and origin of the software.
securityRequirements.title: Authenticate code prior to installation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to verify the integrity of executable code at start up and before loading it into memory.
securityRequirements.title: Check integrity of executable code

securityRequirements.description: The system shall only allow the accepted mobile code and prevent from executing unauthorised ones. Some security policies shall be clearly defined and documented to manage the authorized mobile codes operation.
securityRequirements.note:
Corrective actions when unacceptable mobile code is detected include, for example, blocking, quarantine, or alerting administrators. Blocking includes, for example, preventing transmission of word processing files with embedded macros when such macros have been defined to be unacceptable mobile code.
Actions enforced before executing mobile code, include, for example, prompting users prior to opening electronic mail attachments. Preventing automatic execution of mobile code includes, for example, disabling auto execute features on information system components employing portable storage devices such as Compact Disks (CDs), Digital Video Disks (DVDs), and Universal Serial Bus (USB) devices.
securityRequirements.title: Controls against mobile code

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement security safeguards to protect its memory from unauthorized code execution.
securityRequirements.note:
Some adversaries launch attacks with the intent of executing code in non-executable regions of memory or in memory locations that are prohibited. Security safeguards employed to protect memory include, for example, data execution prevention and address space layout randomization. Data execution prevention safeguards can either be hardware-enforced or software-enforced with hardware providing the greater strength of mechanism.

Security safeguards can either be implemented within the system (as part of the system) or be a COTS or hardware system. In the latter case, the installation of the COTS or hardware system shall be forseen within the integration plan to ensure that such a protection is effecitvely installed.
securityRequirements.title: Protect against unauthorised code execution

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are security controls applicable to source code prior to installation and execution
securityRequirements.title: Code execution and installation

securityRequirements.description: The code used to help the integration (sort of back door) and to debug the logging features shall be suppressed in the operational software or deactivated by not compiling it into the binary.
securityRequirements.note:
This means code used to quickly debug (e.g. printouts) or other quick code hacks that were used to make the integration easier/faster, but are not a functionality of the software.
Debugging features that accept inputs or parameters shall be systematically removed. Debugging outputs shall be removed from all applications requiring confidentiality.
securityRequirements.title: Suppress code used for integration and debug logging

securityRequirements.description:
The source code shall be protected to avoid programming faults and unintended information disclosures.
Access to program source code shall be restricted.
securityRequirements.title: Source code protection

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements concern the integrity of the source code.
securityRequirements.title: Source code security

securityRequirements.description: No servers with default installation configuration shall be used.
securityRequirements.title: Remove default installations

securityRequirements.description: The system shall synchronise its internal clock with the [authoritative time source] every [update frequency].
securityRequirements.note: This provides uniformity of time stamps for information systems with multiple system clocks and systems connected over a network.
securityRequirements.title: Synchronise internal clocks

securityRequirements.description: Minimum resources (database, active directories, and registries) shall be allocated to any user.
securityRequirements.title: Allocate minimum resources

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about the management of system configurations.
securityRequirements.title: System configurations

securityRequirements.description: The system shall only reveal error messages to authenticated users.
securityRequirements.note: Exception of this requirement can be errors that affect the proper functing of the system (e.g. outage notifications).
securityRequirements.title: Reveal error messages only to authorised users

securityRequirements.description: The system shall generate error messages that provide information necessary for corrective actions without revealing information that could be exploited by adversaries.
securityRequirements.note:
Carefully consider the structure/content of error messages. The extent to which information systems are able to identify and handle error conditions is guided by organizational policy and operational requirements. Information that could be exploited by adversaries includes, for example, erroneous logon attempts with passwords entered by mistake as the username, mission/business information that can be derived from (if not stated explicitly by) information recorded, and personal information such as account numbers, social security numbers, and credit card numbers. In addition, error messages may provide a covert channel for transmitting information.

Avoid information leakage via error messages by implementing a proper exception and error handling mechanism.. Ensure that errors from all layers are adequately checked and configured to prevent error messages from being exploited by intruder
securityRequirements.title: Ensure that error messages do not reveal security crucial information

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prevent the display of applications' and servers' default banner.
securityRequirements.note:
Most default banners reveal relevant information on the server and application
Indeed, one of the first tasks when conducting an application penetration test is to try to identify the version of the server and the application to pentest. The reason for that is that it allows the tester to discover all the well-known vulnerabilities that are affecting the server and the application.
This process is called application fingerprinting.
securityRequirements.title: Prevent display of default banner

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that a users operations are unable to be observed by other users.
securityRequirements.note:
This is especially the fact for third parties, that shall not be able to observe that the resource or service is being used. This requires that users and/or subjects cannot determine whether an operation is being performed.

For example, a user shall not be able to observe the a specific web page is used another user, or a user shall not be able to observe that a certain technology is used on the system (i.e. database version/types, PHP usage, etc.).
While this information is not immediatley a threat, it can provide valuable information for an attacker to better target the system's key resources. An attacker could also profit of this information to know which user to target (i.e. target a high priviledged user).

Note that hardware resources also provide valuable information for an attacker, e.g. there was an attack on the smart card reader which, by observing the CPU usage, could determine the length of the key used within a smart card.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure unobservability of operations

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prevent the presentation of information system management-related functionality at an interface for non-privileged users.
securityRequirements.note: This ensures that administration options (e.g., administrator privileges) are not available to general users (including prohibiting the use of the grey-out option commonly used to eliminate accessibility to such information). Such restrictions include, for example, not presenting administration options until users establish sessions with administrator privileges.
securityRequirements.title: Prevent display of management-related functionalities to non-privileged users

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide an explicit indication of current participants in online meetings and teleconferences.
securityRequirements.note: This enhancement helps to prevent unauthorized individuals from participating in collaborative computing sessions without the explicit knowledge of other participants.
securityRequirements.title: Explicitly indicate current participants

securityRequirements.description: For collaborative computing devices, the system shall provide an explicit indication of use to users physically present at the devices.
securityRequirements.note: Collaborative computing devices include, for example, networked white boards, cameras, and microphones. Explicit indication of use includes, for example, signals to users when collaborative computing devices are activated.
securityRequirements.title: Explicitly indicate when collaborative computing devices are in usage

securityRequirements.description: The system shall avoid unauthorised/unintended exposition (display, read, view) of information.
securityRequirements.title: Avoid unauthorised/unintended exposition of information

securityRequirements.description: The system shall�employ external components specifically designed to be the target of malicious attacks for the purpose of detecting, deflecting, and analysing such attacks.
securityRequirements.note: A honeypot is set up as a decoy to attract adversaries and to deflect their attacks away from the operational systems supporting organizational missions/business function.
securityRequirements.title: Employ honeypots

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement underlying hardware separation mechanisms to facilitate process separation.
securityRequirements.note: Hardware-based separation of information system processes is generally less susceptible to compromise than software-based separation, thus providing greater assurance that the separation will be enforced. Underlying hardware separation mechanisms include, for example, hardware memory management.
securityRequirements.title: Use hardware separation to facilitate process isolation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall maintain a separate execution domain for each thread when multi-threaded processing is used.
securityRequirements.title: Isolate processing threads

securityRequirements.description: The system shall maintain a separate execution domain for each executing process.
securityRequirements.note: Information systems can maintain separate execution domains for each executing process by assigning each process a separate address space. Each information system process has a distinct address space so that communication between processes is performed in a manner controlled through the security functions, and one process cannot modify the executing code of another process. Maintaining separate execution domains for executing processes can be achieved, for example, by implementing separate address spaces. This capability is available in most commercial operating systems that employ multi-state processor technologies.
securityRequirements.title: Isolate processes

securityRequirements.description: The system shall minimise the number of nonsecurity functions included within the isolation boundary containing security functions.
securityRequirements.note: Nonsecurity functions contained within the isolation boundary are considered security-relevant because errors or maliciousness in such software, by virtue of being within the boundary, can impact the security functions of organizational information systems. The design objective is that the specific portions of information systems providing information security are of minimal size/complexity. Minimizing the number of nonsecurity functions in the security-relevant components of information systems allows designers and implementers to focus only on those functions which are necessary to provide the desired security capability (typically access enforcement). By minimizing nonsecurity functions within the isolation boundaries, the amount of code that must be trusted to enforce security policies is reduced, thus contributing to understandability.
securityRequirements.title: Minimise the number of nonsecurity included in the security isolation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use underlying hardware separation mechanisms to implement security function isolation.
securityRequirements.note: Underlying hardware separation mechanisms include, for example, hardware ring architectures, commonly implemented within microprocessors, and hardware-enforced address segmentation used to support logically distinct storage objects with separate attributes (i.e., readable, writeable).
securityRequirements.title: Implement hardware separation mechanisms for security function isolation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall isolate security functions enforcing access and information flow control from both nonsecurity functions and from other security functions.
securityRequirements.note: Security functions that are potentially isolated from access and flow control enforcement functions include, for example, auditing, intrusion detection, and antivirus functions.
securityRequirements.title: Isolate access control and flow control functions from other nonsecurity and security functions

securityRequirements.description: Security functions shall be implemented as largely independent modules that avoid unnecessary interactions between modules by limiting module coupling.
securityRequirements.note: The reduction in inter-module interactions helps to constrain security functions and to manage complexity. The concepts of coupling and cohesion are important with respect to modularity in software design. Coupling refers to the dependencies that one module has on other modules. Cohesion refers to the relationship between the different functions within a particular module. Good software engineering practices rely on modular decomposition, layering, minimization to reduce and manage complexity, thus producing software modules that are highly cohesive and loosely coupled.
securityRequirements.title: Avoid unnecessary module interactions

securityRequirements.description: Security functions shall be implemented as cohesive modules.
securityRequirements.note: The concepts of coupling and cohesion are important with respect to modularity in software design. Coupling refers to the dependencies that one module has on other modules. Cohesion refers to the relationship between the different functions within a particular module. Good software engineering practices rely on modular decomposition, layering, minimization to reduce and manage complexity, thus producing software modules that are highly cohesive and loosely coupled.
securityRequirements.title: Implement functions as cohesive modules

securityRequirements.description: The system shall isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions.
securityRequirements.note: The information system isolates security functions from nonsecurity functions by means of an isolation boundary (implemented via partitions and domains) that controls access to and protects the integrity of the hardware, software, and firmware that perform those security functions. Information systems implement code separation (i.e., separation of security functions from non-security functions) in a number of ways, including, for example, through the provision of security kernels via processor rings or processor modes. For non-kernel code, security function isolation is often achieved through file system protections that serve to protect the code on disk, and address space protections that protect executing code. Information systems restrict access to security functions through the use of access control mechanisms and by implementing least privilege capabilities.
securityRequirements.title: Isolate security functions from nonsecurity functions

securityRequirements.description: The system/software shall be deployed in an isolated network.
securityRequirements.title: Deploy system/software in an isolated network

securityRequirements.description: Critial and sensitive systems shall have a dedicated environment isolated for the other systems
securityRequirements.title: Critical and sensitive system segregation

securityRequirements.description: The execution of each component shall be isolated.
securityRequirements.title: Isolate components

securityRequirements.description: Modification of security attributes shall only be possible by specific, well-defined roles.
securityRequirements.note: Security attributes are all data that are used to configure the security features of the system.
securityRequirements.title: Restrict security attributes modification

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that only secure (allowed) values are accepted for security attributes.
securityRequirements.note: Security attributes are all data that are used to configure the security features of the system.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce secure values for security attributes

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce the secure default values for security functions.
securityRequirements.note:
The default values for security function shall reflect the best possible security. In other words, when configurable, the value chosen as default values should always reflect the strongest security available.
For example if a web application has the option between using http and https, the default value should be https. Downgrading to http is then left as advised choice and to the responsibility of the configuring user.
securityRequirements.title: Enforce secure default values for security functions

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about the management of software attributes, configurations and parameters.
securityRequirements.title: Software configurations

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements refer to hardening of systems, servers and applications.
securityRequirements.title: System and software hardening

securityRequirements.description: The system shall fail to a [known-state] for [defined types of failures] preserving [defined system state information] in failure.
securityRequirements.note: Failure in a known state addresses security concerns in accordance with the mission/business needs of organizations. Failure in a known secure state helps to prevent the loss of confidentiality, integrity, or availability of information in the event of failures of organizational information systems or system components. Failure in a known safe state helps to prevent systems from failing to a state that may cause injury to individuals or destruction to property. Preserving information system state information facilitates system restart and return to the operational mode of organizations with less disruption of mission/business processes.
securityRequirements.title: Fail in a known state

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide a safe mode in which the system enters under certain [agreed critical conditions].
securityRequirements.note:
For information systems supporting critical missions/business functions including, for example, military operations and weapons systems, civilian space operations, nuclear power plant operations, and air traffic control operations (especially real-time operational environments), organizations may choose to identify certain conditions under which those systems revert to a pre-defined safe mode of operation. The safe mode of operation, which can be activated automatically or manually, restricts the types of activities or operations information systems could execute when those conditions are encountered. Restriction include, for example, allowing only certain functions that could be carried out under�limited power or with reduced communications bandwidth.

Such such safe modes are be a prevention approach to maintain the system's availability, e.g. by limiting the modification ablities (e.g. read only for some parts), by limiting the possible interactions, by limiting the power, by reducing the communication bandwidth, thereby ensuring the system's persistence during the time of the critical event.
securityRequirements.title: Provide a safe mode

securityRequirements.description: The system shall have a maximum number of [number of allowed failures] failures per [given time span].
securityRequirements.title: Limit the number of failures

securityRequirements.description: The system shall restore its state with the [defined system state information] after crash or reboot.
securityRequirements.note: Ensure that there is no data corruption or loss of data.
securityRequirements.title: Restore state

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to restore in a maximum time of [maximum allowed restore time].
securityRequirements.title: Restore time

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to restore after a crash of failure.
securityRequirements.title: System restore

securityRequirements.description: The system shall correctly react to failures by transitioning to a known state or restoring into safe mode
securityRequirements.title: Handling system failures

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide and alternate communication protocol in support of maintaining continuity of operations.
securityRequirements.note: Alternate communications protocols increase the resilience of information systems. Alternate communications protocols include, for example, switching from Transmission Control Protocol to User Datagram Protocol communications or to a special purpose protocol used in conjunction with the Internet Protocol. Switching communications protocols may affect software applications and therefore, the potential side effects of introducing alternate communications protocols are analysed prior to implementation.
securityRequirements.title: Provide alternative communication protocols

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect the availability of resources by allocating resources by their priority; quota; or other security safeguards.
securityRequirements.note: Priority protection helps prevent lower-priority processes from delaying or interfering with the information system servicing any higher-priority processes. Quotas prevent users or processes from obtaining more than predetermined amounts of resources. This does not apply to information system components for which there are only single users/roles.
securityRequirements.title: Protect resource availability

securityRequirements.description: The distributed system shall ensure that the relevant parts of it know the correct status of transmitted data among its different parts, using acknowledgements.
securityRequirements.note:
Distributed systems may give rise to greater complexity than monolithic systems through the potential for differences in state between parts of the system, and through delays in communication.
In most cases synchronisation of state between distributed functions involves an exchange protocol.

State synchrony protocol establishes the requirement for certain critical functions to use this trusted protocol and�ensures that two distributed parts of the system have synchronised their states after a security-relevant action.
securityRequirements.title: User state synchrony protocol for distributed systems

securityRequirements.description: The system shall manage excess capacity, bandwidth, or other redundancy to limit the effects of information flooding denial of service attacks.
securityRequirements.note: Managing excess capacity ensures that sufficient capacity is available to counter flooding attacks. Managing excess capacity may include, for example, establishing selected usage priorities, quotas, or partitioning.
securityRequirements.title: Manage excess capacity/bandwidth/redundancy

securityRequirements.description: The system shall restrict the ability of internal users/individuals to launch denial of service attacks against other information systems.
securityRequirements.note: Restricting the ability of individuals to launch denial of service attacks requires that the mechanisms used for such attacks are unavailable. Individuals of concern can include, for example, hostile insiders or external adversaries that have successfully breached the information system and are using the system as a platform to launch cyber-attacks on third parties. Organizations can restrict the ability of individuals to connect and transmit arbitrary information on the transport medium (i.e., network, wireless spectrum). Organizations can also limit the ability of individuals to use excessive information system resources. Protection against individuals having the ability to launch denial of service attacks may be implemented on specific information systems or on boundary devices prohibiting egress to potential target systems.
securityRequirements.title: Restrict DoS attacks from internal users

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect against or limit the effects of denial of service attacks by employing security safeguards.
securityRequirements.note: A variety of technologies exist to limit, or in some cases, eliminate the effects of denial of service attacks. For example, boundary protection devices can filter certain types of packets to protect information system components on internal organizational networks from being directly affected by denial of service attacks. Employing increased capacity and bandwidth combined with service redundancy may also reduce the susceptibility to denial of service attacks.
securityRequirements.title: Protect against denial of service

securityRequirements.description: Alternative or supplemental security mechanisms shall be employed for satisfying security functions when the primary means of implementing the security function is unavailable or compromised.
securityRequirements.note: This supports information system resiliency and contingency planning/continuity of operations. To ensure mission/business continuity, organizations can implement alternative or supplemental security mechanisms. These mechanisms may be less effective than the primary mechanisms (e.g., not as easy to use, not as scalable, or not as secure). However, having the capability to readily employ these alternative/supplemental mechanisms enhances overall mission/business continuity that might otherwise be adversely impacted if organizational operations had to be curtailed until the primary means of implementing the functions was restored. Given the cost and level of effort required to provide such alternative capabilities, this control would typically be applied only to critical security capabilities provided by information systems, system components, or information system services. For example, an organization may issue to senior executives and system administrators one-time pads in case multifactor tokens, the organization's standard means for secure remote authentication, is compromised.
securityRequirements.title: Provide alternative security mechanisms

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements permit to ensure reliability of software systems.
securityRequirements.title: Reliability

securityRequirements.description: The system shall able to detect when the limit of storage capacity is reached.
securityRequirements.note: Organisations may have multiple audit data storage repositories distributed across multiple information system components, with each repository having different storage volume capacities.
securityRequirements.title: Detect audit storage capacity reach

securityRequirements.description: The system shall provide a real time alert when audit failure events occur.
securityRequirements.note: Alerts provide organisations with urgent messages. Real-time alerts provide these messages at information technology speed (i.e., the time from event detection to alert occurs in seconds or less).
securityRequirements.title: Alert audit processing failures in real time

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to detect audit processing failures.
securityRequirements.note: Audit processing failures include, for example, software/hardware errors, failures in the audit capturing mechanisms, and audit storage capacity being reached or exceeded.
securityRequirements.title: Detect audit processing failures

securityRequirements.description: As last resort, the system shall invoke a safe operation mode in case of a [major audit failure], unless no alternate audit capacity exists.
securityRequirements.note: This ensures that, in case of a major audit failure, the system runs in a state�(i.e. safe mode) that avoids any possible misuse of the system (since the audit failure may be the result of an attack that tries to make unoticed actions).
securityRequirements.title: Shutdown on major audit failure

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce configurable traffic volume thresholds reflecting limits on auditing capacity related to network traffic volume and reject or delay network traffic above those thresholds.
securityRequirements.title: Permit configurable traffic volume thresholds

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to take the [appropriate action] when an audit processing failure is detected.
securityRequirements.note:
The followings are examples of action: shut down information system, overwrite oldest audit records, stop generating audit records.
Organisations may choose to define additional actions for different audit processing failures (e.g., by type, by location, by severity, or a combination of such factors). This applies to each audit data storage repository (i.e., distinct information system component where audit records are stored), the total audit storage capacity of organizations (i.e., all audit data storage repositories combined) or both.
securityRequirements.title: Take action on audit processing failures

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about audit processing failures.
securityRequirements.title: Audit processing failures

securityRequirements.description: The system shall compile audit records from the all system components/parts into a, centralized, system-wide (logical or physical) audit trail that is time correlated within [level of tolerance for relationship between time stamps of individual records in the audit trail].
securityRequirements.note:
The compilation of audit records implies the format adaptation and time correlation of the logs (i.e. to match the centralized log format and time value) and the forwarding of those records into a centralized log processing facility for log correlation.
Audit trails are time-correlated if the time stamps in the individual audit records can be reliably related to the time stamps in other audit records to achieve a time ordering of the records within organizational tolerances.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure system wide/time correlated audit trails

securityRequirements.description: The system shall notify [incident response personnel (identified by name and/or by role)] of detected suspicious events and takes [least-disruptive actions to terminate suspicious events].
securityRequirements.note: Least-disruptive actions may include, for example, initiating requests for human responses.
securityRequirements.title: Take least-disruptive automated actions to suspicious events

securityRequirements.description: The system shall alert [incident response personnel (identified by name and/or by role)] when unusual / unauthorised activities are detected.
securityRequirements.note: Alerts may be generated from a variety of sources, including, for example, audit records or inputs from malicious code protection mechanisms, intrusion detection or prevention mechanisms, or boundary protection devices such as firewalls, gateways, and routers. Alerts can be transmitted, for example, telephonically, by electronic mail messages, or by text messaging. Organisational personnel on the notification list can include, for example, system administrators, mission/business owners, system owners, or information system security officers.
securityRequirements.title: Alert on unusual/unauthorised activities

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are related to alerts, correlations and reactions based on audit trails.
securityRequirements.title: Audit operations

securityRequirements.description: The system shall backup audit records onto a physically different system or system component than the system or component being audited.
securityRequirements.note: This helps to ensure that a compromise of the information system being audited does not also result in a compromise of the audit records.
securityRequirements.title: Backup audits on separate physical systems

securityRequirements.description: The system shall employ cryptographic mechanisms to protect the integrity of audit information and audit tools.
securityRequirements.note: Cryptographic mechanisms used for protecting the integrity of audit information include, for example, signed hash functions using asymmetric cryptography enabling distribution of the public key to verify the hash information while maintaining the confidentiality of the secret key used to generate the hash.
securityRequirements.title: Cryptographically protect the integrity of audit trails

securityRequirements.description: The system shall write audit trails to hardware-enforced, write-once media.
securityRequirements.note: This applies to the initial generation of audit trails (i.e., the collection of audit records that represents the audit information to be used for detection, analysis, and reporting purposes) and to the backup of those audit trails. It does not apply to the initial generation of audit records prior to being written to an audit trail. Write-once, read-many (WORM) media includes, for example, Compact Disk- Recordable (CD-R) and Digital Video Disk-Recordable (DVD-R). In contrast, the use of switchable write-protection media such as on tape cartridges or Universal Serial Bus (USB) drives results in write-protected, but not write-once, media.
securityRequirements.title: Write audit trails to write-once media

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect audit information and audit tools from unauthorised access, modification, and deletion.
securityRequirements.note: Audit information includes all information (e.g., audit records, audit settings, and audit reports) needed to successfully audit information system activity. This control focuses on technical protection of audit information. Physical protection of audit information is addressed by media protection controls and physical and environmental protection controls.
securityRequirements.title: Protection of audit information

securityRequirements.description: Auditing functions shall be implemented and activated throughout the system.��The grades of activation of audit functions shall be adapted to the situation.
securityRequirements.note:
This requirement ensure that auditing is activated throughout the system to assure that each relevant event is logged. Depending on the type of log and the system state, the auditing functions can be adapted (e.g. verbose mode, minimal audit).

The term "system" is used here to denote at least
- for all physically or logically separated assets and
- for all security application interaction across security classification boundaries.

Further involvement of separate applications can be introduced if agreed in the policy.
Audits records can be generated from many different information system components. Audited events are events for which audits are to be generated. These events are typically a subset of all events for which the information system is capable of generating audit records.
securityRequirements.title: Implement audit functions

securityRequirements.description: The system shall monitor inbound and outbound communications traffic for unusual or unauthorized activities or conditions.
securityRequirements.note:
Unusual/unauthorized activities or conditions related to information system inbound and outbound communications traffic include, for example, internal traffic that indicates the presence of malicious code within organizational information systems or propagating among system components, the unauthorized exporting of information, or signalling to external information systems. Evidence of malicious code is used to identify potentially compromised information systems or information system components.

This requirement can be covered using HIDS and/or NIDS (Host or Network Intrusion Detection Systems).
securityRequirements.title: Monitor inbound and outbound communication traffic

securityRequirements.description: The system shall initiate session audits at system start-up.
securityRequirements.title: Initiate the capture of session audits at start-up

securityRequirements.description: Activities from both privileged and unprivileged accounts shall be logged.
securityRequirements.title: Privileged and unprivileged account logs

securityRequirements.description: The system shall permit to remotely view all content related to an established user session in real time and select the user session to capture/record or view.
securityRequirements.note: Session auditing activities are developed, integrated, and used in consultation with legal counsel in accordance with applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, or regulations.
securityRequirements.title: Remotely view/access session audits

securityRequirements.description: The system shall capture/record all content related to a user session.
securityRequirements.note: Session auditing activities are developed, integrated, and used in consultation with legal counsel in accordance with applicable laws, Executive Orders, directives, policies, or regulations.
securityRequirements.title: Produce session audits

securityRequirements.description: Audit logs recording [audit record types] shall be produced and kept for an [agreed period].
securityRequirements.note:
This shall be produced and kept to assist in future investigations and access control monitoring.
The term "system" is used here to denote at least
- for all physically or logically separated assets and
- for all security�related applications (e.g. anti-virus software, intrusion detection/prevention software),
- for all application interaction across security classification boundaries.

Further involvement of separate applications can be introduced if agreed in the policy.
Audits records can be generated from many different information system components. Audited events are events for which audits are to be generated. These events are typically a subset of all events for which the information system is capable of generating audit records.
securityRequirements.title: Produce audit logs

securityRequirements.description: The system shall be able to provide information on system users for audit purposes.
securityRequirements.title: Enable acquirement of user information

securityRequirements.description: The system shall produce a system-wide (logical or physical) audit trail composed of audit records in a standardized format.
securityRequirements.note: Audit information that is normalised to common standards promotes interoperability and exchange of such information between dissimilar devices and information systems. This facilitates production of event information that can be more readily analysed and correlated. Standard formats for audit records include, for example, system log records and audit records compliant with Common Event Expressions (CEE). If logging mechanisms within information systems do not conform to standardised formats, systems may convert individual audit records into standardised formats when compiling system-wide audit trails.
securityRequirements.title: Use standardised audit formats

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use the internal system clock to generate time stamps for audit records.
securityRequirements.note: Generated time stamps shall be mapped to Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) or Greenwich Mean Time (GMT).
securityRequirements.title: Audit timestamps

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are related to audit record information.
securityRequirements.title: Audit record information

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements permit to track information systems activities and potentially discover unauthorized actions and errors.
securityRequirements.title: Monitoring

securityRequirements.description: Define if transport layer or message-layer security shall be used.
securityRequirements.title: Define the security layer to be used

securityRequirements.description: The security protection of the data involved in electronic transaction shall be ensured. Mechanisms to protect against malicious activities, contracts dispute or repudiation, and all other confidentiality and integrity flaws shall be implemented.
securityRequirements.title: E-commerce

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect against automated probing by using captchas for user inputs.
securityRequirements.note: Typically, captchas are used as a first barrier for input fields (e.g. forms, search fields) to confirm that the user is a human and not an automated script.
securityRequirements.title: Protect information via captchas

securityRequirements.description: Online dealings shall be protected against information security problems and incidents. Examples of suche incidents are incomplete transmission and all unauthorized message alteration, disclosure, duplication or replay.
securityRequirements.title: On-line transactions

securityRequirements.description: The system shall also prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources when system processing explicitly switches between different information classification levels or security categories.
securityRequirements.note: This applies when there are explicit changes in information processing levels during information system operations, for example, during multi-level processing and periods processing with information at different classification levels or security categories. Organisation-defined procedures may include, for example, approved sanitization processes for electronically stored information.
securityRequirements.title: Prevent unauthorised transfer when switching between classifications

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prevent unauthorized and unintended information transfer via shared system resources.
securityRequirements.note: This prevents information, including encrypted representations of information, produced by the actions of prior users/roles (or the actions of processes acting on behalf of prior users/roles) from being available to any current users/roles (or current processes) that obtain access to shared system resources (e.g., registers, main memory, hard disks) after those resource have been released back to information systems. The control of information in shared information system resources is also referred to as object reuse. This control does not address: (i) information remanence which refers to residual representation of data that has been nominally erased or removed; (ii) covert channels (including storage or timing channels) where shared resources are manipulated to violate information flow restrictions; or (iii) components within information systems for which there are only single users/roles.
securityRequirements.title: Prevent unauthorised transfer via shared resources

securityRequirements.description: The integrity of publicly available information system shall be protected to prevent any integrity modification.
securityRequirements.title: Protect integrity of information published through available system

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover security implications associated with using services, including on-line transactions, and the requirements for controls.
securityRequirements.title: Service provision security

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use secure methods to generate random numbers.
securityRequirements.title: Use secure methods to generate random numbers

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure secure cryptographic keys destruction following a defined method.
securityRequirements.title: Securely destroy your keys

securityRequirements.description: The system shall enforce change of cryptographic keys at a [defined-key-change-interval].
securityRequirements.note: The appropriate key management can be done via a PKI.
securityRequirements.title: Periodically change your keys

securityRequirements.description: The system shall generate cryptographic keys offline with a specified key size in accordance with a validated cryptographic key generation algorithm.
securityRequirements.note: Cryptographic keys shall not be generated over insecure network.
securityRequirements.title: Securely generate your keys

securityRequirements.description: The transmission of sensitive keys shall be ensured over secure channel in accordance with a specified cryptographic key distribution method.
securityRequirements.title: Securely transmit your keys

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure secure access to cryptographic keys.
securityRequirements.title: Securely access your keys

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about the management of cryptographic keys.
securityRequirements.title: Cryptographic key management

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements cover the security around the usage of cryptography, cryptographic algorithms, their configuration and parameters.
securityRequirements.title: Cryptography management

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement cryptographic mechanisms to protect message externals (e.g. message headers/routing information) unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.
securityRequirements.note: This addresses protection against unauthorized disclosure of information. Message externals include, for example, message headers/routing information. This control enhancement prevents the exploitation of message externals and applies to both internal and external networks or links that may be visible to individuals who are not authorized users. Header/routing information is sometimes transmitted unencrypted because the information is not properly identified by organizations as having significant value or because encrypting the information can result in lower network performance and/or higher costs.
securityRequirements.title: Protect message externals

securityRequirements.description: The system shall maintain reviewer/releaser identity and credentials within the established chain of custody for all information reviewed or released.
securityRequirements.note: If the reviewer is a human or if the review function is automated but separate from the release/transfer function, the information system associates the identity of the reviewer of the information to be released with the information and the information label. In the case of human reviews, this control enhancement provides appropriate organizational officials the means to identify who reviewed and released the information. In the case of automated reviews, this control enhancement ensures that only approved review functions are employed.
securityRequirements.title: Maintain chain of custody for reviewer/releaser

securityRequirements.description: The system shall associate the identity of the information producer with the information and provides a mean for authorised individuals to determine the identity of the producer of the information.
securityRequirements.note: This supports audit requirements that provide organisational personnel with the means to identify who produced specific information in the event of an information transfer. Organisations determine and approve the strength of the binding between the information producer and the information based on the security category of the information and relevant risk factors.
securityRequirements.title: Associate the identity of users to the information

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that a subject that receives information during a data exchange is provided with evidence of the origin of the information�(which can then be verified).
securityRequirements.note: Non-repudiation of origin ensures that the originator of information cannot successfully deny having sent the information.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure non-repudiation of origin

securityRequirements.description: The system shall prevent modification of information between review and transfer/release by validating the binding of the information to the information reviewer identity.
securityRequirements.note: The validation of bindings can be achieved, for example, by the use of cryptographic checksums.
securityRequirements.title: Validate the binding of the reviewer identity

securityRequirements.description: The system shall ensure that a subject that transmits information during a data exchange is provided with evidence of receipt of the information (which can then be verified).
securityRequirements.note: Non-repudiation of receipt ensures that the recipient of information cannot successfully deny receiving the information.
securityRequirements.title: Ensure non-repudiation of receipt

securityRequirements.description: The system shall validate the binding of the information producer identity to the information and performs [validation errors appropriate actions] in the event of a validation error.
securityRequirements.note: This prevents the modification of information between production and review. The validation of bindings can be achieved, for example, by the use of cryptographic checksums. Organisations determine if validations are in response to user requests or generated automatically.
securityRequirements.title: Validate the binding of the information producer identity

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect against an individual falsely denying having performed an action by using non-repudiation mechanisms.
securityRequirements.note: Types of individual actions covered by non-repudiation include, for example, creating information, sending and receiving messages, approving information (e.g., indicating concurrence or signing a contract). Non-repudiation protects individuals against later claims by: (i) authors of not having authored particular documents; (ii) senders of not having transmitted messages; (iii) receivers of not having received messages; or (iv) signatories of not having signed documents. Non-repudiation services can be used to determine if information originated from a particular individual, or if an individual took specific actions (e.g., sending an email, signing a contract, approving a procurement request) or received specific information. Organizations obtain non-repudiation services by employing various techniques or mechanisms (e.g., digital signatures, digital message receipts).
securityRequirements.title: Use information non-repudiation mechanisms

securityRequirements.description: SSL renegotiation triggered by the client side shall be disabled.
securityRequirements.title: Disable client-side SSL renegotiation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall only use SSL version 3 (SSLv3) or above.
securityRequirements.title: Minimum SSL version

securityRequirements.description: SSL ciphers shall authenticated for both client and server. Anonymous mode of SSL cannot be used.
securityRequirements.note: To prevent Man-In-The-Middle attacks against SSL, anonymous cipher suites shall be disabled on both web browsers and servers. Although anonymous SSL cipher suites are deactivated by default in recent web browsers, thus preventing already the use of anonymous cipher suites, anonymous SSL cipher suites shall also be disabled on the target web servers.
securityRequirements.title: Only use authenticated ciphers

securityRequirements.description: SSL encryption shall only use keys of at least 128 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Minimum key length of 128 bits

securityRequirements.description: The system shall only use TLS version 1.2 or above.
securityRequirements.title: Minimum TLS version

securityRequirements.note: These requirements are about authentication and encryption using Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) or Transport Layer Security (TLS).
securityRequirements.title: SSL/TLS based authentication and encryption

securityRequirements.description: For Java implementations, the bouncy castle library shall be used for AES-GCM.
securityRequirements.title: (Java) Should use bouncy castle library

securityRequirements.description: The AES-GCM algorithm shall be used with a key size of 128 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Use 128 bits keys (recommended)

securityRequirements.description: The AES-GCM shall be used with a key size of at least 128 bits.
securityRequirements.note: Larger values are allowed.
securityRequirements.title: Use at least 128 bits keys (larger values allowed)

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements concern the AES-GCM algorithm key size.
securityRequirements.title: AES-GCM key length

securityRequirements.description: For encryption in combination with data integrity and origin authentication, the system shall use AES in Galois/Counter Mode (GCM).
securityRequirements.note: The cryptographic community has recognized that data encryption without data origin authentication often results in degraded security. As a result, several additional counter modes of operation that provide both encryption and data origin authentication have been specified. These modes are called Authenticated Encryption with Associated Data (AEAD). GCM can provide very high-speed authenticated encryption in hardware as well as in software. It can also be parallelized and pipelined, methods that can be very advantageous in the space community. It also does not require padding with extraneous, throwaway bits.
securityRequirements.title: Use AES-GCM algorithm

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use authenticated encryption for the [type of space data for authenticated encryption].
securityRequirements.title: Authenticated Encryption

securityRequirements.description: The RSA Digital Signature Algorithm key length shall be no less than 2048 bits.
securityRequirements.note: The Digital Signature Standard allows three different RSA modulus sizes to be used to construct the RSA public/private keys. The allowed sizes are 1024, 2048, 3072 bits. CCSDS has chosen to use a minimum modulus of 2048 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Minimum key length of 2048 for RSA

securityRequirements.description: The Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) Algorithm shall be used when using digital signature technology for user authentication.
securityRequirements.note:
For spacecraft without the ability to contact a key server to obtain public keys, a public key cache can be pre-loaded prior to launch or public keys may be uploaded after launch or when additional keys or updated keys need to be loaded. This is probably not an issue for ground systems which are assumed have robust network communications and access to a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) or Certificate Authority (CA).
RSA is an algorithm for public-key cryptography that is based on the presumed difficulty of factoring large integers, the factoring problem.
securityRequirements.title: Use the RSA algorithm

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA).
securityRequirements.note:
The Digital Signature Standard specifies several algorithms to construct and verify digital signatures: the Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA); the RSA Digital Signature Algorithm; and Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA).
ECDSA requires that the private/public key pairs used for digital signature generation and verification be generated with respect to a particular set of domain parameters. These domain parameters may be common to a group of users and may be public. Domain parameters may remain fixed for an extended time period.
For spacecraft without the ability to contact a key server to obtain public keys, a public key cache can be pre-loaded prior to launch or public keys may be uploaded after launch or when additional keys or updated keys need to be loaded. This is probably not an issue for ground systems which are assumed have robust network communications and access to a Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) or Certificate Authority (CA).
securityRequirements.title: Use ECDSA algorithm

securityRequirements.description: Alternate algorithms or parameters can be used if agreed with the TO.
securityRequirements.note: The use of alternative hash algorithms or parameters must be agreed upon a priori or must be signalled via management to ensure compatibility and interoperability among mission components.
securityRequirements.title: Alternative PKI algorithms

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use the Digital Signature Standard (DSS) when using digital signature technology.
securityRequirements.note:
A digital signature is represented in a computer as a string of bits. A digital signature is computed using a set of rules and a set of parameters that allow the identity of the signatory and the integrity of the data to be verified. Digital signatures may be generated on both stored and transmitted data.
Reference: Digital Signature Standard (DSS). Federal Information Processing Standards Publication 186-3. Gaithersburg, Maryland: NIST, June 2009.
securityRequirements.title: Use DSS for digital signatures - PKI

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use SHA-256 for authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Use SHA-256

securityRequirements.description: The system shall not truncate the length of the MAC resulting from HMAC.
securityRequirements.title: Do not truncate the MAC length

securityRequirements.description: The system shall not truncate the length of the MAC resulting from HMAC, except if functional mission constraints (e.g., bandwidth, storage, frame size, packet size) require it.
securityRequirements.note:
The truncation must be agreed upon a priori or must be signalled to the receiver(s) to ensure compatibility and interoperability.

HMAC had been specified in FIPS 198a (an earlier version of HMAC) as a ten step process with the final step performing the truncation of the message authentication code by selecting only the leftmost t-bits from the total of L-bits generated by the hash algorithm. For SHA-1, the 160-bit MAC could be truncated to 96-bits. The latest HMAC revision found in FIPS 198-1 removes the final truncation step from the algorithm specification. Truncation is now addressed in NIST Special Publication 800-107. Truncation results in less bits being transmitted over the communications link which means reduced authentication algorithm overhead. By not transmitting the entire message authentication code, some additional security strength may be achieved since anyone intercepting the message will not obtain the full MAC, thereby limiting any possible cryptanalysis. However, there is potentially more security strength achievable at the receiver if all of the hash bits must be matched rather than just truncated t-bits. The security community is not unanimous one way or the other on the merits of truncation.
securityRequirements.title: Truncate the MAC length ONLY if needed

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements concern MAC truncation.
securityRequirements.title: MAC truncation

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use SHA-512 for authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Use SHA-512

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use SHA-224 for authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Use SHA-224

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use SHA-384 for authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Use SHA-384

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use RIPEMD-160 for authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Use RIPEMD-160

securityRequirements.description: Alternate algoritims or parameters can be used if agreed with the TO.
securityRequirements.note: The use of alternative hash algorithms or parameters must be agreed upon a priori or must be signaled via management to ensure compatibility and interoperability among mission components.
securityRequirements.title: Alternative HMAC algorithms

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use hash based authentication using the HMAC algorithms.
securityRequirements.note: Hash-based Message Authentication Codes (HMACs) algorithms utilize cryptographic hash functions with low probability of collisions (e.g., SHA-256) and a shared secret (key). The data to be authenticated is concatenated with the shared secret and then the hash algorithm is run over the concatenated data resulting in a fixed size Message Authentication Code (MAC).
securityRequirements.title: Hash based - HMAC algorithms

securityRequirements.description: The AES algorithm shall be used with a key size of at least 128 bits.
securityRequirements.note: Larger values are allowed.
securityRequirements.title: Use at least 128 bits keys (larger values allowed)

securityRequirements.description: The AES algorithm shall be used with a key size of 256 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Use 256 bits keys

securityRequirements.description: The AES algorithm shall be used with a key size of 192 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Use 192 bits keys

securityRequirements.description: The AES algorithm shall be used with a key size of 128 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Use 128 bits keys

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements concern the AES algorithm key size.
securityRequirements.title: AES keys length

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use the AES algorithm for authentication.
securityRequirements.note: The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) specifies a cryptographic algorithm that can be used to protect electronic data. The AES algorithm is a symmetric block cipher that can encrypt (encipher) and decrypt (decipher) information
securityRequirements.title: Use AES

securityRequirements.description: The Galois Message Authentication Code (GMAC) shall be used in place of CMAC when an authenticated encryption implementation is used for authentication only.
securityRequirements.note: That is the AES-GCM algorithm. GCM is a mode of operation of the AES algorithm.
securityRequirements.title: Use GMAC in case of Authenticated Encryption

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use cipher based authentication using the CMAC algorithms.
securityRequirements.note:
The CMAC algorithm depends on the choice of an underlying symmetric key block cipher. The CMAC algorithm is thus a mode of operation (a mode, for short) of the block cipher. The CMAC key is the block cipher key (the key, for short).
For any given key, the underlying block cipher of the mode consists of two functions that are inverses of each other. The choice of the block cipher includes the designation of one of the two functions of the block cipher as the forward function/transformation, and the other as the inverse function.
securityRequirements.title: Cipher based - CMAC algorithms

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use authentication for the [type of space data for authentication].
securityRequirements.title: Authentication

securityRequirements.description: The AES algorithm shall be used with a key size of 128 bits.
securityRequirements.title: Use 128 bits keys

securityRequirements.description: The AES algorithm shall be used with a key size of at least 128 bits.
securityRequirements.note: Larger values are allowed.
securityRequirements.title: Use at least 128 bits keys (larger values allowed)

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements concern the AES algorithm key size.
securityRequirements.title: AES keys length

securityRequirements.description: For encryption in the system shall use Advanced Encryption Standard (AES).
securityRequirements.note: The Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) specifies a cryptographic algorithm that can be used to protect electronic data. The AES algorithm is a symmetric block cipher that can encrypt (encipher) and decrypt (decipher) information
securityRequirements.title: Use AES algorithm

securityRequirements.description: Alternate algorithms or parameters can be used if agreed with the TO.
securityRequirements.note: The use of alternative hash algorithms or parameters must be agreed upon a priori or must be signalled via management to ensure compatibility and interoperability among mission components.
securityRequirements.title: Alternative encryption algorithms

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use encryption for the��[type of space data].
securityRequirements.title: Encryption

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are extracted from the CCSDS Recommended Standard for security algorithms.
securityRequirements.title: CCSDS Cryptography

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use Security Association (SA) as defined in CCSDS 355.0-R-2 to configure, format and transmit the necessary security parameters for encryption, authentication and/or authenticated-encryption.
securityRequirements.title: Use Security Associations

securityRequirements.description: For all space data systems, the CCSDS standard for Space Data System Communication Cryptography and Security Protocol shall be used.
securityRequirements.title: CCSDS Space Data System Communication Cryptography and Security Protocol

securityRequirements.description: The system shall implement cryptographic mechanisms to conceal or randomize communication patterns unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.
securityRequirements.note: This addresses protection against unauthorised disclosure of information. Communication patterns include, for example, frequency, periods, amount, and predictability. Changes to communications patterns can reveal information having intelligence value especially when combined with other available information related to missions/business functions supported by organizational information systems. This control enhancement prevents the derivation of intelligence based on communications patterns and applies to both internal and external networks or links that may be visible to individuals who are not authorized users. Encrypting the links and transmitting in continuous, fixed/random patterns prevents the derivation of intelligence from the system communications patterns. Alternative physical safeguards include, for example, protected distribution systems.
securityRequirements.title: Conceal/randomise communications

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use replay-resistant authentication mechanisms for network access.
securityRequirements.note: Authentication processes resist replay attacks if it is impractical to achieve successful authentications by replaying previous authentication messages. Replay-resistant techniques include, for example, protocols that use nonces or challenges such as Transport Layer Security (TLS) and time synchronous or challenge-response one-time authenticators.
securityRequirements.title: Employ replay resistant authentication mechanisms

securityRequirements.description: The system identification and authentication parameters shall detect and be protected against interception and replay attacks.
securityRequirements.note: Various types of entities (e.g. messages, service requests, service responses) are concerned and subsequent actions to correct. In the case where replay may be detected, this effectively prevents it.
securityRequirements.title: Protect against interception and replay attacks

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use cryptographic mechanisms to prevent unauthorized disclosure of information and/or detect changes to information during transmission unless otherwise protected by alternative physical safeguards.
securityRequirements.note: Encrypting information for transmission protects information from unauthorized disclosure and modification. Cryptographic mechanisms implemented to protect information integrity include, for example, cryptographic hash functions which have common application in digital signatures, checksums, and message authentication codes. Alternative physical security safeguards include, for example, protected distribution systems.
securityRequirements.title: Protect transmitted information using cryptography or alternate protections

securityRequirements.description: The system shall protect the confidentiality, integrity and authentication of transmitted information using cryptographic means.
securityRequirements.note: This applies to both internal and external networks.
