Organisations relying on commercial providers offering transmission services as commodity services rather than as fully dedicated services (i.e., services which can be highly specialized to individual customer needs), may find it difficult to obtain the necessary assurances regarding the implementation of needed security for transmission confidentiality/integrity. In such situations, organisations determine what types of confidentiality/integrity services are available in standard, commercial telecommunication service packages. If it is infeasible or impractical to obtain the necessary security through appropriate contracting vehicles, organisations implement appropriate compensating security controls or explicitly accept the additional risk.
securityRequirements.title: Communication cryptography

securityRequirements.description: The system shall create a new session cookie after each user authentication or re-authentication.
securityRequirements.note: This ensures that the cookie cannot be stolen by an attacker and that it cannot be used after an authentication.
securityRequirements.title: Create a new session cookies after each (re)authentication

securityRequirements.description: Old session cookie shall be destroyed on the server side immediately after (re)authentication and logout.
securityRequirements.note: This prevents an attacker from keeping the old cookie alive.
securityRequirements.title: Delete old session cookies right after use

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use security attributes for all critical cookies.
securityRequirements.note:
Attributes such as 'secure' or 'HttpsOnly' should be used.
The 'secure' property ensures that the cookie is sent only when using the HTTPS transport protocol. This protects against disclosure of the session cookie when the end-user accidentally access unprotected resources over HTTP (even images, or CSS scripts).
It is also recommended to use the property 'HttpsOnly', which is implemented in all major web browsers. This property limits the use of a cookie by client-side scripts, thus avoiding a cookie theft through XSS attacks.
securityRequirements.title: Use cookie security attributes

securityRequirements.description: The system shall not use the same cookie for anonymous pages than the one used for authenticated pages and vice versa.
securityRequirements.title: Use different cookies for anonymous and authenticated pages

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use a cookie based authentication to identify devices.
securityRequirements.title: Cookie based authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall authenticate devices before establishing local/remote/network connection using a cryptographically based bidirectional authentication.
securityRequirements.note: A local connection is any connection with a device communicating without the use of a network. A network connection is any connection with a device that communicates through a network (e.g., local area or wide area network, Internet). A remote connection is any connection with a device communicating through an external network (e.g., the Internet). Bidirectional authentication provides stronger safeguards to validate the identity of other devices for connections that are of greater risk (e.g., remote connections).
securityRequirements.title: Use cryptographic bidirectional authentication

securityRequirements.description: The system shall map the authenticated identity to the account of the individual.
securityRequirements.title: Map the authenticated identity to the account

securityRequirements.description: The system shall validate certificates by constructing a certification path with status information to an accepted trust anchor.
securityRequirements.note: Status information for certification paths includes, for example, certificate revocation lists or certificate status protocol responses.
securityRequirements.title: Validate certification paths

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use the X.509 standard as cryptographic system.
securityRequirements.note:
X.509 is a widely used standard for defining digital signatures. It is actually an�ITU-T Recommendation, which means that it has not been officially defined for standardized use.

The main feature of the Public Key Infrastructure with X.509 certificates are Certification Authority (CA) and Registration Authority (RA).
�- CA is the entity that issues digital certificates. It is an example of Trusted Third Party (TTP). The CA attests that the public key contained in the certificate belongs to the person, organization, server, or other entity noted in the certificate.
�- RA refers to persons, processes and tool used for supporting the registration of users with PKI and administration of users. They vouch for binding between public keys and certificate holder entities.

Certificate holders can sign and decrypt digital documents using private keys.
Clients validate digital signatures and their certification paths from known public key of trusted CA and encrypt documents using public key from certificates of certificates holders.
securityRequirements.title: X.509

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) as cryptographic system.
securityRequirements.note:
PGP is a public key cryptographic package, which is intended for public usage.

It provides sender authenticity, message integrity and non-repudiation of the sender. Although PGP can encrypt any data or files, it is most commonly used for e-mail which has no built-in security as originally implemented.
For that time it has been sufficiently influential that its algorithms and data formats have been standardized for interoperability between different pieces of software.

PGP combines symmetric and asymmetric cryptography. The user generates a pair: (public key,private key) that is associated with his unique ID. Public keys are stored on public key rings and private keys are stored on private key rings. On the sender?s side, PGP creates a session key, which is random number generated by the keystroke characteristics of a user. Once the data is encrypted with this key, the session key is encrypted with the recipient?s public key and sent together with the cipher text to the recipient. The recipient?s copy of PGP uses her private key to recover the session key, which then allows the recipient to decrypt the cipher text.
securityRequirements.title: PGP

securityRequirements.description: The system shall use PKI-based authentication and validate certificates by constructing a certification path with status information to an accepted trust anchor
securityRequirements.note:
Devices requiring unique device-to-device identification and authentication may be defined by type, by device, or by a combination of type/device. Information systems typically use either shared known information (e.g., Media Access Control [MAC] or Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol [TCP/IP] addresses) for device identification or organizational authentication solutions (e.g., IEEE 802.1x and Extensible Authentication Protocol [EAP], Radius server with EAP-Transport Layer Security [TLS] authentication, Kerberos) to identify/authenticate devices on local and/or wide area networks.

A local connection is any connection with a device communicating without the use of a network. A network connection is any connection with a device that communicates through a network (e.g., local area or wide area network, Internet). A remote connection is any connection with a device communicating through an external network (e.g., the Internet).
securityRequirements.title: Digital signature based authentication (PKI)

securityRequirements.description: The system shall establish a trusted communications path between the user and the sensitive security functions of the system (e.g. system authentication and re-authentication).
securityRequirements.note: Trusted paths are mechanisms by which users (through input devices) can communicate directly with security functions of information systems with the requisite assurance to support information security policies. The mechanisms can be activated only by users or the security functions of organizational information systems. User responses via trusted paths are protected from modifications by or disclosure to untrusted applications. Organizations employ trusted paths for high-assurance connections between security functions of information systems and users (e.g., during system logons). Enforcement of trusted communications paths is typically provided via an implementation that meets the reference monitor concept.
securityRequirements.title: Provide trusted communications path between users and sensitive security function

securityRequirements.description: The system shall request and perform data origin authentication and data integrity verification on the name/address resolution responses that the system receives from authoritative sources.
securityRequirements.note: Each client of name resolution services either performs this validation on its own, or has authenticated channels to trusted validation providers. Information systems that provide name and address resolution services for local clients include, for example, recursive resolving or caching domain name system (DNS) servers. DNS client resolvers either perform validation of DNSSEC signatures, or clients use authenticated channels to recursive resolvers that perform such validations. Information systems that use technologies other than the DNS to map between host/service names and network addresses provide other means to enable clients to verify the authenticity and integrity of response data.
securityRequirements.title: Employ secure name/address resolution services

securityRequirements.description: The system shall uniquely identify and authenticate devices/external systems/separated parts of the system before establishing a local/remote/network connection.
securityRequirements.note:
Devices requiring unique device-to-device identification and authentication may be defined by type, by device, or by a combination of type/device. Information systems typically use either shared known information (e.g., Media Access Control [MAC] or Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol [TCP/IP] addresses) for device identification or organizational authentication solutions (e.g., IEEE 802.1x and Extensible Authentication Protocol [EAP], Radius server with EAP-Transport Layer Security [TLS] authentication, Kerberos) to identify/authenticate devices on local and/or wide area networks.

A local connection is any connection with a device communicating without the use of a network. A network connection is any connection with a device that communicates through a network (e.g., local area or wide area network, Internet). A remote connection is any connection with a device communicating through an external network (e.g., the Internet).
securityRequirements.title: Device-to-device identification, authentication

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are about protection of communications.
securityRequirements.title: Communication protection

note: The following requirements are relevant during the project for design, architecture and development processes.
title: Functional Requirements

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall include the whitelist of users authorized to access the various systems in the user account management documentation in the [host document].
securityRequirements.note:
When OS services are based on user accounts, only the required subset of users shall be granted access.
This requirement means that the common rule should be to prevent users to use services like FTP. Access should be granted only on a case-by-case basis
securityRequirements.title: Only grant access to a subset of user accounts

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall include the deletion of inactive accounts in the user account management documentation in the [host document].
securityRequirements.note:
The old and inactive accounts should be deleted.
This prevents illicit use of accounts by other users.
securityRequirements.title: Delete inactive accounts

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall include the modification of the default password after software installation in the user account management documentation in the [host document].
securityRequirements.title: Change default password after installation

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall include the deactivation of default accounts in the user account management documentation in the [host document].
securityRequirements.note:
Default or standard accounts / account names (e.g. Guest) shall be disabled.
These accounts are an easy target even for not-too-experienced attackers.
securityRequirements.title: Disable default accounts

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall document the user account management in the [host document]
securityRequirements.note: This includes configuration integration of new accounts, handling of old/inactive accounts, privileges for the accounts, etc.
securityRequirements.title: Define user account management

securityRequirements.description: The assumptions on system environment shall be aligned to the CIG.
securityRequirements.note: E.g. deployment environment (physical and logical location), network, user access, ...
securityRequirements.title: Define assumptions on system environment

securityRequirements.description: The backup strategy/policy shall be defined in the CIG.
securityRequirements.title: Define backup strategy

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall document for all compilers used, the selected implementation options.
securityRequirements.title: Document compiling options

securityRequirements.description: All relevant logs that need to be analysed for the system shall be described on the CIG.
securityRequirements.title: Document relevant logs

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall document in the CIG the third party software used by the software system and clearly stating the type, if commercial or open source. For each open source software the type of license shall be specified and included on the delivery CD.
securityRequirements.note:
This includes COTS (Commercial Of The Shelf) and any other third party software not developed under supervision or approval of ESA.
The delivery CD contains a licence overview file containing all types of licence used and their associated licence file.
securityRequirements.title: Document the third party software licensing

securityRequirements.description: The contractor shall document the specific hardening steps taken to restrict access to the target system/software.
securityRequirements.title: Define access hardening steps

securityRequirements.description:
All executable, libraries, configuration files, tools of a particular service shall be grouped (if possible) and stored in directories owned by the appropriate role. Modification/write access rights shall be denied for all other users.
This shall be documented in the CIG.
securityRequirements.note: This requirement applies to the files dedicated to the applications (services).
securityRequirements.title: Group and restrict access to particular service files

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are related to the CIG.
securityRequirements.title: CIG

securityRequirements.description: For each external and internal interface, the interface characteristics, security requirements, and nature of the information communicated shall be documented in an ICD.
securityRequirements.note: This applies to dedicated connections between information systems and between organizational information systems and (separate) constituent system components (i.e., intra-system connections) including, for example, system connections with mobile devices, printers, copiers, facsimile machines, scanners, and sensors.
securityRequirements.title: Specification of information system connnection

securityRequirements.description: The information flows shall be documented in the ICD.
securityRequirements.note: E.g. ports used.
securityRequirements.title: Define information flows

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are related to the ICD.
securityRequirements.title: ICD

securityRequirements.description: The Software Release Notes (SRN) shall contain or describe the location of checksums for the application's files.
securityRequirements.note: Checksums permit to check the integrity of the files and should therefore be provided. Integrity checks shall rely on cryptographic Message Authentication Code (MAC)
securityRequirements.title: Provide checksum

securityRequirements.note: The following requirements are related to the SRN.
securityRequirements.title: SRN
